texts.en:
Maximo has a home on a piece of land that was given to him by his father. On his land he only has a few chickens and also some pigs. With the loan he hopes to invest in rice for the upcoming season. He will buy seeds, fertilizer, and pesticides. He has two children, both of whom are still at home going to school. He hopes that, with the additional income, he can continue to feed his family and educate his two sons.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

He is part of one of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Primero de Agosto Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. They will use the microloans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each other's guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but Mifex believes that it is imperative for the communities it works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The sector is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with the rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water from the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

payments.comment: 1er pago asociacion 1 de agosto de sta lucia

texts.en:
Felipe has a small piece of land that he inherited from his father. He primarily produces rice, although he also plants other crops such as corn. He lives with his 15 year old daughter and his wife. He hopes that with the loan he can make his land more productive for rice, as now it is not level and he needs to rent machinery to level it out. With the extra profits he wants to educate his daughter or help her start a business of her own.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

texts.en:
Baldomero is a farmer from the Santa Lucia area. He has a small piece of land that was given to him and his brothers by his father. He primarily produces rice on his part of the land. He lives with his wife and children on his land, with his brothers nearby. They are a very close knit family who help each other out by working cohesively on their lands. He hopes that with the loan he can make his land more productive for rice, as now it is not level and he needs to rent machinery to level it out. With the extra profits he wants to improve his home which is in poor condition.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Baldomero is part of one of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Primero de Agosto Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but Mifex believes that it is imperative for the communities it works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

texts.en: Radil was born in 1988 in Salyan region, Yenikand village, and is single. Three years ago this young man decided to start his own business. He wants to help his parents cover family expenses, and is applying for a loan of $400 to buy 2 calves to improve his cattle-breeding.

Yaver is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan, Fizuli region, Kurdmakhmudlu village. He is married and has a child.
He previously borrowed a loan of $400, bought a cow, and has run this business for 6 years.
Now he needs a loan of $800 to buy 2 calves.

loans.name: Bisansio Juma

texts.en: Bisansio is married and as yet has no children. He has not undertaken any formal training and he is an active member of the community’s drug awareness team. He started his business in 2003. This is his second loan with PEMCI. He has finished his first loan successfully, which has enabled him to expand his business and he has been able to open another shop and provide employment to his younger brother. With a second loan from PEMCI, Bisansio plans to strengthen his second shop and stock it fully so as to be able to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: Bisansio would like to boost his business

texts.en:
This 45-year-old man is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region, Gayidish village, is married and has 3 children. Five years ago he started his own business, and he works very hard for the success of his children. 
Now he needs a loan of $1000 to buy a milk cow.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a widow. She has five children, three in secondary and two in primary schools. She is a trained primary school teacher and she teaches at a nearby school. She started her business last year in order to supplement her salary. She gets her stock from the farmers during harvest seasons and sells them when the supply is low. This is her second loan with PEMCI. The first loan enabled her to expand her business, so she was able to pay school fees for her children in secondary school, and she was also able to develop her farm. With a second loan from PEMCI, she intends to increase her stock further.

loans.use: Rose would like to boost her stock for her grocery store.

texts.en: Farzhana lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a tailor. She is married and lives with members of her family and she wants to help her husband support her family. She wants to take a group loan to expand her business and buy new machines because she wants to send her children to good schools to be educated. She hopes that if she works hard to be a good business dealer in the future she will make a good monthly income for her family.

Tamasha has 6 years of experiences in this business, and she wants to expand her sheep breeding. She has 4 sheep. 
Now she needs a loan of $800 to buy 10 sheep, to raise her income level.
Tamasha is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region, Makhmudlu 2 village, and is married with 2 children.

loans.name: Mark

texts.en: Mark is married but as yet has no children. His business includes selling herbal medicines which he gets from all over the country. He has been in the business for three years and says the business is booming. With a loan from PEMCI, Mark wishes to increase his stock.

loans.use: Mark would like to boost his stock of herbal medicines.

texts.en:
Norzia lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married, living with her husband. She always wants to support her family. Her husband is the driver of a water tanker. He sells water to those people who don’t have water. he need for money and his wife’s wants to take a group loan for her husband to repair the body of his truck to be able to expand his business and help his family. He would like to thank AFSG for supporting their family.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband of the entrepreneur. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to some people to post a picture of a woman to the Internet. However, the loan is to the female entrepreneur. AFSG only makes group loans to women.

loans.name: Roshel

texts.en: Roshel is married with four children all in primary school.  She is a primary school drop out and hasn’t undergone any formal training. She started her business in 1990 in order to sustain her family as her husband is not employed. First she started in a small canteen and with time it developed into a shop. This is her second loan with PEMCI; the first loan enabled her to increase her stock and also enabled her to start a food store next to her shop. With a second loan from PEMCI, she intends to increase her food store stock. Through her business, she has been able to support her family and educate her children.

loans.use: Roshel would like to increase her stock for her mini shop.

loans.name: Nor Zia

texts.en:
nor zia lives in district 17 of Kabul Afghanistan she is married living with her husband she always wants to support her family and her husband is driver of water tanker he sale water for those peoples to they don’t have water he need for money and his wife’s wants to take a group of loan and her husband wants to make a new body for his car to expand his business and help his family and he would like to thank from AFSG to support them. 
Note; the picture featured in this business profile. Husband of entrepreneur. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur. AFSG only does group loans to woman.

loans.use: to change the body of car

texts.en:
Sahila lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and lives with her husband. She doesn’t have children. Her husband is a shopkeeper who has a retail food shop. His wife took her 3rd cycle group loan and her husband expanded his shop. His wife wants to take anther loan for her husband to buy some extra materials like powder, Pepsi Cola, baskets, flour and some other things to make a good business and help his wife better than now.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the husband of entrepreneur. In Afghanistan, it is culturally unacceptable to some people to post a picture of a woman to the Internet. However, the loan is to the female entrepreneur. AFSG only makes group loans to women.

Tariyel is 47, is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of  Azerbaijan, Fizuli region, Bala Behmenli village. He is married and has one child. He has run this business for 4 years, and this is his only source of income.
Now he needs a loan of $600 to buy a calf to improve his business.

loans.name: Nagiba

texts.en: Nagiba lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is an uneducated woman. She is single. She wants to help her family because her father is dead and her brothers are in school and she is the one to help her family. She has a farm and she wants to take a group loan to buy some animals like a cow and sheep to raise them and sell the milk to people so that she can make a good life for her family.

loans.use: To buy a cow and sheep

texts.en: Palosha lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is an uneducated woman and she is single. She wants to earn more money to make a good life for herself. She has a bakery and she wants to improve her business. She wants to take a group loan to enlarge her business and find more clients.  She is very happy with this loan and she would like to thank AFSG for helping her.

Nageba lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a widow whose husband died during the war. She is supporting her family and she has good experience as a tailor. She took her 3rd loan cycle to buy new sewing machines. She can support her family well and now she wants to take another loan to open a new shop and buy some equipment that she needs. She is very happy now that she can support her family.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Daniel will use the loan to expand and diversify his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: George intends to expand and diversify his business

texts.en: Nadia lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is the last person in her family. All the members of her family were killed in a rocket attack. She is living with her uncle but she doesn’t want her uncle to support her. She wants to support herself. She is gardener and now she wants to take a group  loan to start a flower farm and sell flowers in the bazaar to make a good life for herself. She is very happy about this loan because she can support herself. She would like to thank AFSG.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand and diversify his furniture-making business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy chickens and chicken feed for her poultry farming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To diversify and expand his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand and diversify his cyber cafe business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Monica will use the money to diversify and expand her business.

texts.en: Qaria lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a tailor. She wants to help her husband to support them. All their sons are married and they live somewhere else. She took her 3rd cycle group loan and opened a shop in her house and bought all the materials she needed. Now she wants to take anther loan to buy new sewing machines and some chairs.

Nasimjon has been working as a hairdresser for 13 years already. He has his own salon by the house. He likes his job, but the income from this business is not enough for a big family. He has two children and helps his elderly parents and brothers. The whole family lives with him in one house, so Nasimjon has to keep domestic animals and engage in trading fodder. His last loan he received for fodder grain, which he gets from the local coarse-grinding mill, and sells in the city market in Khujand. His next loan he plans to use for purchasing a hog and some sheep.

Munira J. and her husband work at the secondary school. She is a teacher of the native language and a teacher of the knitting group. They have three girls. Munira dreams of two of her daughters becoming doctors and the other one a teacher. Munira and her husband used their first loan to purchase a bull. Now they plan to purchase another two bulls. It will take them approximately $1500 USD. They have their savings and hope to receive the requested loan.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his butchery business to include a mini restaurant

texts.en: On May 5,2007, Ismatullo’s wife bore a daughter. It is a big happiness for his family because while they had one son already, they could not have more children for 20 years. The doctors had to deliver the baby by cesarean section to keep her alive. To have enough milk for the little girl, Ismatullo purchased a dairy cow. Now Ismatullo has a plan to reconstruct his house and extend the space for his household. His request for a loan is to purchase hogs and sheep. Ismatullo has been working for 23 years at a music school. He teaches children to play the national instrument, the “doyra”. He likes his job but says that livestock is the business of his family. It is passed from one generation to another.

Juraboy has 5 children and 13 grandchildren. He had worked at a local farm for 33 years, and 12 years at an airport in the security department. Now, for 15 years, he has been engaged only in livestock activity. He has a big family and 3 of his sons and their children live with him in one house.

Last year he experienced a great misfortune with his daughter. After a family assault and battery from her husband, she was badly burned and stayed alive for 35 days. Juraboy spent all his savings to safe the life of his daughter. Unfortunately, she died and he now cares for her two children. The next loan Juraboy will use to purchase sheep and profit from his business for his children.

Khaidarboy’s elder son works in Russia to make money for a house and wedding. Another one also is also going to Russia to save money for his education. Livestock helps Khaidarboy to feed his family.  He purchases 4 hogs at a time including fodder for them. After some months, he sells them at the local livestock market. 

He plans to purchase another set of hogs and to save money for his son to travel to Russia.

Abdumajid is a teacher of physics. Due to his small salary he had to leave his favorite job and engage in trading. He opened a food shop. The goods he delivers are from Khujand central market. But the idea to teach children never left him, and with his last loan he decided to purchase computers. Now he has a room for computer games and his two sons help him there. He has also purchased a copy machine and scanner.

Now he requests a loan for tables and chairs, which he will rent for his business.

loans.name: Devota

texts.en: Devota lives in Lumo, Temeke District in Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children and her eldest daughter is in secondary school. Devota runs a tailoring business from the verandah of her home. The business has not been good recently due to insufficient sewing materials and competition she faces from her neighbors. She wants to improve her business by having enough sewing material supplies and renting a business premise. Devota is currently working on the verandah of her house which does not attract customers and does not provide her enough space. She also needs to add two sewing machines and one assistant. Her strategy requires a capital injection of $550.

loans.use: Devota would like an assistant, two sewing machines and to add sewing material supplies for her tailoring business.

texts.en:
Nabieva S. has been engaged in trading since her youth. She likes her job and it helps her and her family. She has three children and two grandchildren. Her husband is the driver of a microbus. Her two sons are  metal turners.

They are a friendly family and live together in one house. With her last loan she increased her assortment of toys. Now she plans to open another section in her shop to sell household goods.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth lives in the Lumo area of Dar es Salaam. She owns a fruits and vegetables stall. She fetches some of the fresh produce like tomatoes and spinach from local farmers nearby her residence. Other items like cabbages, onions, potatoes, coconuts, groundnuts, pepper and spices she fetches from the main market. Elizabeth wants to increase the quantity of her stock to overcome shortages. She is also planning to have cages for hygiene products and to create an attractive display. This will make her product offering more attractive and therefore increase sales. To fulfill these requirements she is in need of $400 to subsidize her capital.

loans.use: Elizabeth would like to add to her stock of supplies for her fruit and vegetable stand.

texts.en:
Rokhatoy is a pharmacist with a lot of experience. Previously, she worked in a government drugstore, and then she decided to start her own business. She started her business from the market. Now she has purchased a premise for her drugstore.
Rokhatoy has many clients from the neighboring country of Kirgystan (the border is near to their place). They have friendly relations, which contributes to international co-operation. Now her clients have asked her to open a wedding salon on her other premise. She plans to use her next loan for design and dresses for the wedding salon. 

As for her family, Rokhatoy has 3 children and 8 grandchildren. Her eldest daughter’s marriage was not successful. She is a teacher and, unfortunately, her husband is a drug addict and she had to leave him. Now Rokhatoy helps her daughter and her grandchildren.

Zarrina used to work at the local TV station. She is lively and likes to communicate with people. After her marriage, her husband did not allow her to work there anymore. Now she works at the local market and sells perfume. But Zarrina wants to work in Russia. The reason is that she cannot have children, and Zarrina is very sad due to this. She wants to save money for her health, and thinks that only in Russia can she get the right treatment. Her next loan will be used for increasing her assortment of perfumes. During this season she could make more money.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en: Hadija lives in the Buza area, on the outskirts of Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children and she sells maize flour to shops and food vendors. She prepares the flour by herself. She buys the maize in retail, sends it to the milling machine and packs the product in packets of 5-10 kilograms. She also sells bi-product as animal feed. She is planning to increase her stocks of maize as she is usually faced with being out-of-stock. To meet her planning target she is need of $1000.

loans.use: Hadija would like to add to her stock of maize.

texts.en:
Gavhkar has been working at the market for 12 years. Since the beginning she has traded sweets. She receives loans for expansion of her assortment of goods and she uses the profits for her family. There are 12 people living in their house: two of her sons, her husband, her parents–in-law and her brother –in-law. Her elder son has graduated from the agriculture institute and, like his father, works at the local farm. Another son helps her at the market. They have to save money for his wedding and to purchase another house for him. 

It is cold in the winter and very hot in the summer to work in an open-air market. Gavhkar plans to rent a premise for sweets-shop.

You can see in the picture a very kind woman, who lives in the Salyan region, in Yenikand village. Sevil is married and has 4 children.
This 57-year-old woman breeds cattle to meet the demands of her family.  It is very difficult to bring up 4 children. 
She needs a loan of $600 to buy a pregnant cow, so she will be able to increase the number of her cattle and provide a better living for her children.
Sevil has been in this business for 3 years.

loans.name: Mwazani

texts.en:
Mwazani is married with five children. She lives in the Lumo area of Dar es Salaam. Mwazani sells “khanga”, a type of cloth worn by women, which is fitted around the waist. The cloth is very famous to indigenous residents of Dar es Salaam called “Wazaramo”. This type of cloth is mainly used during traditional festivals of the Zaramo people, but it is used as casual wear to most women in Tanzania.
Mwazani sells these khanga to her customers on credit. She collect the debt on a monthly basis. This situation prompts her to have enough working capital to make her business continuous; so that she can add the stock on time without waiting for the debtors to pay their debts. Mwazani is in need of $550 to facilitate her business.

loans.use: Mwazani would like to add to her stock of clothes.

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en:
Munavvar works alone to support her 3 children, parents in-law and her paralyzed husband. Her husband worked for many years at the carpet-factory in Kayrakum, and two years ago he became sick. When Munavvar is at the market, her children look after their father. Her elder daughter wants to be a lawyer.

Before, Munavvar sold food goods. Then, after receiving a loan from Microinvest, she changed her business. The spare parts she trades she brings in from Khujand. Her request for a loan is to increase her turnover, because most of her profit she now uses for medicine to her husband.

loans.use: Increase her stock of parts to trade

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chickens and chicken feed for her farming business

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en: Zaituni is married with one child. She runs a retail shop near her residence selling different consumable items, food in particular. Since she started this shop three years ago, she noticed only minimal improvements until she attended “Business and Entrepreneurship Training”, from YOSEFO. She is very delighted with the recent improvements. What draws her back is lack of enough working capital. Due to her weak capital base she is likely to lose some customers as she is usually faced with being out of stock. To sustain her stock level she is in need of $550 to strengthen her working capital. The amount will be used to add stock of some items, especially those with high turnover.

loans.use: Zaituni would like to add stock of items with high turnover

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase two dairy cows and cattle feed

texts.en:
Monicah W. K. is a married woman, age 25. She has two kids of her own and another one whom she has to take care of. Monicah did a course in pharmacy but due to the recent competition in that field, she was unable to secure a job. She was so stressed out that her mother, having sufficient experience in poultry farming, advised her on starting the same business.

Monicah did quite well and her business really picked up. She however does not have enough money to expand the business and now she is requesting a loan of US$ 600. She will use US$ 300 to buy more poultry, US$120 to prepare a place to keep the chickens, and US$ 180 to buy poultry feed. She is certain that this will work well for her.

loans.name: Ezinah

texts.en:
Ezinah I. is a 58-year-old nurse who lives with her husband and their four children in Kisumu, Kenya. Two of her children are joining University by September this year.

Ezinah trained as a nurse in the year 1969. After training, she worked in government hospitals for 35 years. In 2005, she opened her own clinic (Mt Everest Medical Clinic) in Manyatta, one of the most densely populated slums of Kisumu. In her clinic she offers general curative services, family planning, counseling, and maternal and child health care services, and also has integrated a pharmacy and laboratory within the clinic. She, in collaboration with K-MET, sells safe motherhood vouchers to expecting poor mothers, which enables them to access reproduction health services in certain medical facilities.

Ezinah attributes her success to hard work, perseverance, and assistance from K-MET’s microfinance loan. She has been able to renovate her facility, purchase a stock of drugs, and improve the quality of care she provides. Ezinah plans buy drugs and equipment for her pharmacy with the US $1200 loan.

loans.use: Improve stock of drugs at the clinic

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy meat for his butchery business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock for his general merchandise shop

texts.en:
Ms. Samanta has been a distributor of cheeses and sausages for one year. "I am a single mother and I have dedicated myself to distributing cheese and sausage, which my family sends to me from the city of San Pedro, Coahuila, in order to support my children, but I have very little money invested and I would like to invest more in order to have more earnings. I am requesting $1,000.00 for this investment."

<Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry, feed, and build a chicken shed

loans.name: Ndeye

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the twenty women of the Femmes de Nder association, led by Ndeye D.. This group has already taken and repaid one Kiva loan – you can check out their previous journal entries and more photos of the group members at http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=154. In this loan application, the group described their business as follows:

“Objectives: To make it possible for the women to remain on their land by giving them the chance to earn substantial income in order to meet their basic living needs. Activities: Harvesting and sale of local incense [note: this incense is made from the roots of the grass that grows in the Senegal River and is popular in markets throughout Senegal], in addition to small-scale retail sale of local products. [The incense-selling business] will consist of harvesting the incense roots where they grow and then processing them into incense which will be sold in the local market and in the other markets of Senegal.”

Original French business description:

«Objectifs :

- Fixer les femmes dans leur terroir

- Leurs permettrent d’avoir des revenus substantiels pour la prise en charge de leurs besoins prioritaires ;

Activités :

Exploitation de l’encens au niveau local

Petit commerce

Il s’agit de chercher la matière première sur place et ensuite le traiter avant de le vendre dans le marché local comme dans les autres localité du Pays.»

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. The SEM Fund works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Homemade incense production - harvesting expenses, storage jars, and transportation to market

loans.name: Ndeye

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the thirty women of the Deggo de Nder association, led by Ndeye S.. In their loan application, the group described their business as follows:

“Objectives: To make it possible for the women to remain on their land by giving them the chance to earn substantial income in order to meet their basic living needs. Activities: Harvesting and sale of local incense [note: this incense is made from the roots of the grass that grows in the Senegal River and is popular in markets throughout Senegal], in addition to small-scale retail sale of local products. [The incense-selling business] will consist of harvesting the incense roots where they grow and then processing them into incense which will be sold in the local market and in the other markets of Senegal.”

Original French business description:

- Leurs permettrent d’avoir des revenus substantiels pour la prise en charge de leurs besoins prioritaires ;

Activités :

Exploitation de l’encens au niveau local

Petit commerce

Il s’agit de chercher la matière première sur place et ensuite le traiter avant de le vendre dans le marché local comme dans les autres localité du Pays.»

Background

Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. loans.use: Homemade incense production - harvesting expenses, storage jars, and transportation to market

texts.en: Sreng Chen I. is 40 years old, and lives with his wife and one child in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Sreng works with his wife on a farm growing a variety of crops and raising animals. He typically makes around $10/day from his plantation. His child attends school and assists in the house work after school.  Sreng has asked for a $1000 loan to purchase a pumping machine, pipe, fertilizer, and seed to increase farm production. Moreover, he plans to grow more crops and raise more pigs in an effort to meet the great demand in the market and from his current clients. Eventually, this family hopes to own another piece of land to grow even more vegetables for purchase by wholesalers and his customers.

loans.name: Tey

texts.en:
Tey S. V. is 32 years old and lives with his wife and his child in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  He makes his living by operating a tuk tuk (a passenger taxi cart attached to a motor bike) and typically makes around $4/day. His wife (pictured here because V. is unavailable), meanwhile, runs a business at home selling duck eggs, roast beef, chickens, local wine, and other grocery products. She normally earns about $25/day in revenue. Their child attends school and usually helps to sell at home when she finishes class. In order to help finance his household, Tey has asked for a loan to purchase another tuk tuk such that he may generate more income.
Additionally, Tey and his wife are eager to one day expand the amount of grocery items sold at their stand.

loans.use: To purchase a tuk tuk to run his business

loans.name: Mark

texts.en:
Mark A. is 30 years old, single, and lives with two dependants, a boy and a girl, who are members of his extended family. One of the dependant’s parents died due to HIVAIDS and the other was abandoned during the 1992 land clashes in the Transmara region of Kenya. He lives with them within Kayole, Kenya.

In 2004 Mark ventured into the business sector by doing tailoring and dressmaking, which he did for 3 years. The business capital was provided by Kenya Agency of Development and Entrepreneurial Technology (KADET), a World Vision micro-finance wing. A loan of Ksh 56,000.00 (USD 800) enabled him to buy sewing machines and clothing materials and he was later able to settle the loan. A golden opportunity from the World Vision emerged and got him a tender to make school uniforms for four schools within Kayole. 

In 2005, as a form of business expansion, Mark started a mobile phone repair shop and sale of mobile phone accessories. He employed 3 orphans who had gone through technical skills training sponsored by World Vision. Besides offering mobile phone charging services, the number of clients seeking phone repairs has greatly increased. He is currently not able to serve his customers effectively since he lacks computers and power flashers that enable detection of a problem in the phone software hence he incurs extra costs in having to seek that kind of service in the city centre, 20 kilometers from his business location. 

Mark is requesting for a loan of (USD 650) to enable him purchase a computer and power flashers. This will enable him to detect the problem in the phone software and to do repairs. This will help improve the profit margins by cutting down on costs of transportation and consultation services from other dealers and also bring flashing services closer to other technicians operating within Kayole. The business will also create employment for the people of Kayole. The loan is repayable within 12 – 18 months.

loans.use: Purchase of power flashers and a computer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a Crisps making machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a blow dryer and a dryer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a jiko (cooking stove), a box of chips storage and a chips cutting machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Esther would like to buy metallic pots to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Julia would like to buy crates of milk for her family's milk business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Margaret would like to buy paraffin for resale and paint her rental houses

loans.name: Anne Dorothy

texts.en:
Anne is a married woman with two children aged 2.5 years and 7 months. She operates a hair salon business in a town suburb. She has been in this business for six years.

Ann, a professional teacher, managed to start the salon business with money she saved. The extra income has helped to improve the standard of living of the family.

Anne's salon is located near Makerere University and has a high number of student clients. Private entrepreneurs have opened up hostels to accommodate the increasing number of students at the university. This has increased the demand for her services.

She needs to improve her services by stocking more cosmetics and improving the place of work. She wishes to borrow $675 to buy more cosmetics. In the future, she hopes to borrow more funds to purchase better salon equipment to serve more clients.

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics for hair salon

loans.name: Chay

texts.en: Chay L. is a mother of four children living with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She runs a tailoring business and typically makes about $3/day in revenue. Her husband is a photographer and a motor-taxi driver. He usually earns around $12/day, which he contributes to the household. One of Chay’s daughters currently works at the nearby local garment factory. Their wages assist in meeting the family's financial needs, especially the needs of the two youngest children. Chay hopes the loan will allow her to purchase a sewing machine and a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi.  In the future, the couple hopes to save enough money to own a photography shop and supplement their children's education.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and a sewing machine for a business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Teresia would like buy seven bundles of iron sheets

texts.en: Anastasia K. is 57 years old and has run an agricultural business since 1990. Previously she worked in the state agricultural company in Silistra. Now she has her own 300-square-meter greenhouse in which she grows tomatoes and cucumbers. She also farms 10 decares of land on which she grows onions, cabbages, carrots, potatoes, and other crops. She sells her crops in the city cooperative market. Anastasia is asking for a  loan of $1200 that she will use to buy seedlings.

Ivanka D. is 34 years old and lives with her husband in the village of Babuk, near Silistra. She and her husband were unemployed and decided to  start their own farming business four years ago. They currently have four cows. She is asking for this loan of $1200 to buy two more cows.

loans.name: Karani

texts.en: Karani I. is 48 years old and lives with his family in the village of Babuk, near Silistra. His two sons live abroad. He and his wife keep four cows and 3 calves in a cowshed near their house. His small dairy produces about 40 liters of milk a day, which he sells to one of the biggest milk companies in the region. Karani I. is asking for a  loan of $1200, which he will use to make some repairs to his cowshed.

loans.use: To make some repairs to his cowshed

loans.name: Kosio

texts.en: Kosio K. is a carpenter. He worked for a private company for two years but then decided to start own business. Six years ago he opened a small carpentry workshop in the town of Alphatar, near Silistra. His business grows every year, and now Kosio provides employment to more than 10 people in the town. Finished goods are exported mainly to Italy. Kosio K. is single and lives with his parents. He is asking for a $1200 loan to buy a special cutting machine.

loans.use: To buy a special cutting machine

texts.en: Velina M. is a 69-year-old widow whose husband died 6 years ago. Previously Velina worked in a state company that manufactured socks and tights in Sliven. Four years ago she and her son bought a knitting machine and started their own business. Now she  and her son have hired two employees to help in the workshop. Their knitted goods are sold on the biggest market in the town of Dimitrovgrad. Velina M. is asking for a loan of  $1200 to buy yarn and thread.

Rasmiya was born in 1964 in the village of Yenikand in the Salyan region. She is married and has one child. Six years ago, she started a business raising hens.
She is asking for a loan of $600 to buy 70 Indian guinea hens.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds and prepare her farm for her farming business

texts.en:
This young man has run a carpentry shop for 4 years. He enjoys his work very much, even though it is sometimes difficult.
Mardan is 26 years old and lives in the village of Yenikand in the Salyan region. He is single.
He is asking for a loan of $400 to buy joiner's bench.

Ruslan was born in 1978 in the village of Yenikand in the Salyan region. He is married and has 2 children. 
Ruslan started a business raising calves 3 years ago.
He is asking for a loan of $600 to buy a pregnant cow to enlarge his herd.

Hakim was born In 1945 in the village of Yenikand in the Salyan region. He went into business as a farmer 20 years ago. With the income from the farm, he supports his wife  and 6 children. 
He is asking for  a loan of $1000 to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase the resources needed to start his flower farming business

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia runs a convenience store in the Villa Ingenio zone of El Alto. Her husband is a police officer, and they have three kids, ages 10, 7 and 3. They live in their own house in the same area as the store. The income Patricia and her husband make helps them take care of their family.

The loan will be used to increase supplies in the store, which will allow her to satisfy the growing demand for her products. This will allow her to be able to improve the quality of life for her family.

This is her second loan, and her credit history makes her a good candidate to receive another loan to help strengthen her business and increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Patricia es comerciante de Abarrotes en la Zona Villa Ingenio de la Ciudad de El Alto, el esposo presta servicio en la Policía, tiene 3 hijos de 10, 7 y 3 años, vive en casa propia ubicada en la misma zona del negocio. Los ingresos que generan Patricia y esposo le permite la manutención de su familia. El destino del crédito es para incrementar mercadería, lo que le permitirá satisfacer la cantidad de demanda que existe en su negocio e incrementar sus ventas para poder ofrecer mejores condiciones de vida para su familia. Es el segundo crédito, su buen antecedente le permite acceder a otro crédito para poder fortalecer su actividad comercial e incrementar sus ingresos económicos.

loans.use: Buy more products for convenience store.

texts.en:
Marco Antonio lives with his parents in the Tupac Amaru area of La Paz. He's a 31-year-old professional chef, a graduate of the Hotelera de La Paz culinary school. He prepares lunch and frozen foods at a government office, and with the variety of foods he makes now he started a business selling foods in El Alto, an affluent city. With this new clientele, he needs to purchase more ingredients and kitchen utensils to grow his business.

IMPRO approved an earlier loan for Marco Antonio, which he used to finish his studies at culinary school and start his job as a chef. The loan was repaid punctually, so he is person with a good credit history and an expanding business.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Marco Antonio vive en casa de sus padres ubicado en la calle puerto Ilo Nª 323 de la zona de Tupac Amaru de la Ciudad de La Paz, tiene 31 años de edad y es de profesión cheff egresado de la escuela Hotelera de La Paz. Se dedica a la atención del almuerzo y refrigerios en una Institución Pública, por la variedad de comidas que el realiza actualmente instalo un negocio de comidas en la Ciudad de El Alto donde la afluencia de gente es muy buena lo cual le obliga a incrementar sus insumos y enseres de cocina para ampliar el negocio. Impro le aprobó un primer crédito, el mismo que fue utilizado para terminar sus estudios en la Escuela Hotelera y posteriormente para iniciar su actividad como Cheff. Este crédito fue cancelado puntualmente, por consiguiente se trata de un cliente con un buen antecedente crediticio y un negocio en expansión.

payments.comment: early pay off. Client is applying for a new loan.

texts.en:
Fernanda works with her husband, Mario Vargas, selling popular regional cuisine and ice cream. They have four vendors working in the business districts of La Paz and El Alto. They have two children and live in their own home, located in the Satellite City (because it's more than 12,000 feet high) area of El Alto. The income helps them provide for their family.

The loan will be used to purchase an ice cream maker to improve the quality of her ice cream.

This is the fourth loan she has solicited. Her credit history makes her a good candidate to receive another one and further increase her family's income and create more job sources.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Fernanda trabaja con su esposo Mario Vargas, realizan trabajo de gastronomía popular, (Salteñas y Rollos de Queso) y Helados, tiene 4 vendedores los cuales trabajan en la comercialización en las Ciudades de La Paz y el Alto.Tiene 2 hijos y vive en casa propia ubicada en la Zona de Ciudad Satélite (denominada así por que se halla a mas de 4000 mts de altura) en la ciudad de El Alto. Los ingresos que generan Fernanda y Esposo le permite la manutención de su familia. El destino del crédito es para comprar una Heladera para la mejor la calidad de producción de los Helados. Este es el cuarto crédito que solicita; su buen antecedente crediticio le permite acceder a otro crédito para mejorar sus ingresos familiares y crear fuentes de trabajo.

loans.name: Arturo

texts.en:
Arturo makes decorations and ornaments for popular social functions called "prestes" in Bolivia. He makes his items with fine cardboard, silky ribbons and bright paper. He doesn't have any employees, but his university-age sons help him with the decorating. He is a widower and all the responsibility to cover family expenses falls on his shoulders. He lives in the Alto San Pedro area of La Paz, which is also where he keeps his workshop. His work depends exclusively on orders from businesses in La Paz, and he has contracts by the dozen.

His file describes him as a client who fulfills his payment obligations on time. The loan he is currently requesting will be used to buy materials like cardboard, ribbon, bright-color paper and glue. His work and his credit history make him an excellent candidate for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Arturo elabora trabajos artesanales de cotillones, adornos y otros para acontecimientos sociales populares llamados prestes en Bolivia. Su trabajo lo realiza con cartulina, adornado con papel seda, y papel brilloso, no cuenta con empleados ya que sus hijos le ayudan en la elaboración, es viudo y el único que se encarga de los gastos familiares de sus dos hijos que están en edad universitaria Vive en la zona de Alto San Pedro de la ciudad de La Paz, y allí mismo se halla ubicado su taller. Su producción total la entrega para su comercialización a negocios exclusivos para este rubro en la ciudad de La Paz, ya que solo trabaja a pedido y tiene contratos por docena. Su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente con cumplimiento regular en el pago de su obligación. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de materia prima (cartulina, papel brilloso, papel seda, y pegamentos). Su trabajo y antecedentes crediticios con Impro le permiten acceder a este crédito.

loans.use: Buy cardboard, ribbon, bright paper, glue, etc.

loans.name: Adelio

texts.en:
Adelio makes party favors, piñatas and fixes up at party sites. She shapes the piñatas with plastic, and, as you can see in the photo, makes a lot of them for infants. She works with her husband, who is in charge of delivering her products to other parts of the country outside of La Paz.

She lives in the Chijini area of La Paz, which is also where her workshop is located. The party favors and piñatas are sold on a popular city street where all kinds of things for special social functions (birthdays, weddings, baptisms, etc.) are sold.

This is her second request for a loan, and she successfully fulfilled her payment obligation the first time. This current loan will be used to purchase plastics, glue, acrylics, ribbon and other decorative items. Her work experience and her credit history make her an excellent loan candidate.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Adelio elabora trabajos manuales- artesanales de cotillones, piñatas y arreglos de local de fiestas. El trabajo de piñatas lo realiza con plastoformo y se trata de (como se puede ver en la foto) de piñatas infantiles. Trabaja con su esposa la que se encarga de entregar su producto en otras zonas del país fuera de La Paz. Vive en la zona de Chijini de la ciudad de La Paz, donde también es su taller, los cotillones y piñatas entrega en la calle Illampu de la ciudad de La Paz, ya que es ahí donde se vende todo articulo de acontecimientos sociales especialmente para cumpleaños infantiles, matrimonios, bautizos y otros. Su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente 2, es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de sus obligaciones. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de insumos como plastoformo, pegamentos, acrilex, cintas y adornos. Su trabajo y antecedentes crediticios con Impro le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio, el cual le da ingresos para cubrir el préstamo solicitado.

loans.use: Purchase plastics, glue, acrylics, ribbon and other decorative items.

loans.name: Ascencio

texts.en:
Ascencio lives in his own home in the Las Lomas area of La Paz. He's 36 years old and a professional carpenter. His employer pays him a moderate salary, so in his free time he builds furniture (for the kitchen, dining room, etc.) to supplement his income. The loan he's requesting would be used to buy raw materials (wood, varnish, etc.).

His file describes him as a good client who always fulfills his obligation. His work and credit history make him an excellent loan candidate.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Ascencio vive en casa propia en la calle Mantilla de la zona de las lomas de la Ciudad de La Paz tiene 36 años de edad, de profesión carpintero, trabaja en una carpintería como empleado donde le pagan un salario semanal moderado, por lo tanto a su vez el en sus tiempos libres se dedica a la elaboración de muebles de cocina, comedores etc. con el fin de poder incrementar sus ingresos. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de materia prima ( madera, clefa, barniz, etc.) Su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente bueno en el pago de su obligación. Su trabajo y antecedente crediticio con Impro le permite acceder a este crédito

loans.use: Buy raw materials (wood, varnish, etc.) to build furniture.

payments.comment: Loan payoff. Ascencio is going to apply for another loan, so in order to do so he is paying off the current loan.

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana lives in her own home and the Villa Nuevo Potosí area of La Paz with her youngest daughter. She's 57 years old and sells athletic shoes for all ages and genders. She started in 1997 selling in the street, and now, thanks to an earlier loan which helped increase her supplies, she now has a sales post and sells her shoes during the afternoons. Along with this business, she opened a convenience store two months ago, and it has done very well. The loan she's requesting would be used to add more products and increase supplies in the store. Her credit history makes her an excellent candidate for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Juana vive en casa propia en la calle Cumana de la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí de la Ciudad de La Paz con su hija menor; ella tiene 57 años de edad, vende zapatos deportivos de mujer, varón, niños, e inicio su actividad en el año 1997 vendiendo en la calle, posteriormente se beneficio con un crédito en Impro con lo cual pudo aumentar su mercadería y actualmente ya tiene un puesto de ventas en la calle tumusla, donde vende por las tardes, además de este negocio ella inicio recientemente otra actividad: instalo una tienda de Abarrotes hace dos meses donde le va muy bien. El crédito que ella solicita es para aumentar productos y poder surtir su tienda. Su antecedente histórico con Impro, la califica como muy buena cliente por consiguiente puede ser acreedora a un nuevo crédito.

loans.use: Buy more products for her convenience store.

loans.name: Hilda Yaneth

texts.en:
Hello! My name is Hilda and I have a shop selling new clothing in the main square of my town. I have been in business for a number of years and have a good clientele. I am a single mother with two kids in school and thanks to my shop I can support them. Thank you!

Translated by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Hola mi nombre es Hilda, mi actividad es el comercio cuento con un negocio de venta de rupa nueva ubicado en la plaza de mi ciudad, tengo varios años de dedicarme a este negocio, cuento con buena clientela, gracias a este negocio puedo cubrir los gastos familiares, soy madre soltera tengo 2 hijos los que estan estudiando gracias.

loans.use: To purchase underwear, jeans, men's shirts, women's blouses and other clothing.

loans.name: Emilio

texts.en:
Emilio is a carpenter and he does all his work with wood. He does not have full-time workers, but hires them on specific jobs when he has a lot of work. He lives in the Villa San Antonio Alto region of La Paz, which is also where his workshop is. He works comes from client orders, and he makes the most on jobs working on furniture.

He is a second-time client here, and he fulfilled his initial loan with no problems. This new loan would be used to purchase raw materials and building supplies (wood, nails, sandpaper, glue, etc.). His work and his credit history make him an excellent candidate for a loan, since he already knows the business, which will give him the money to repay it.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

El Señor Emilio es Carpintero y elabora todo trabajo en madera, no cuenta con empleados fijos ya que cuando tiene muchas obras contrata empleados por obra realizada, pagandole al mismo un porcentaje de la ganancia.. Vive en la zona de Villa San Antonio Alto de la ciudad de La Paz, donde también es su taller, su trabajo lo realiza a pedido, y sus mayores ingresos son por arreglo de todo tipo de muebles Su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente 2, es decir con cumplimiento regular en el pago de su obligación. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de materia prima (Madera, Venesta, clavos, lijas y pegamento). Su trabajo y antecedentes crediticios con Impro le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio. El cual le da ingresos para cubrir el préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials and building supplies (wood, nails, sandpaper, glue, etc.).

loans.name: Virginia Del Carmen

texts.en:
My name is Virginia Z. and I make and sell tortillas. I have been in business three years and have excellent customers. I sell the tortillas I make in various grocery stores in my neighborhood and also cater for parties and other gatherings. My daughter helps me in my work. My goal is to increase my inventory so I can sell more and better support my family.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Mi nombre es Virginia Z. me dedico a la produccion y venta de tortillas, tengo mi negocio hace unos 3 años, mis clientes son excelentes ya que mi producto lo vendo en diferentes pulperias de mi localidad y tambien vendo para reuniones y fiestas, tengo la ayuda de mi hija para la produccion de mis tortillas, mi meta es incrementar mi inventario para tener mayores ventas y con las ganancias que obtenga poder mantener mi familia.

loans.use: To purchase firewood, lime and corn.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Hilda Yaneth

texts.en: Hola Mi nombre el Hilda, mi actividad principal es el comercio, cuento con un negocio de venta de ropa, ubicada en la plaza de mi ciudad, tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de actividad, la que me genera ingresos para cumplir con los gastos familiares  y de estudio de mis hijas ya que soy madre soltera

loans.use: Compra de Ropa  interior, pantalones de tela Jeans, camisas de baron, bluma de dama y otros

loans.name: Rene Adolfo

texts.en:
Hello! My name is Rene and I sell candy and snacks in the center of my town. I have been doing this for a number of years. Thanks to the sweets cart I can support my mother, who is older and unmarried.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Hola Mi nombre es Rene, mi actividad principal es el comercio cuento con una chiclera en el centro de mi ciudad, tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de negocio, ya que gracias a este negocio puedo ayudar a mi madre, siendo ella soltera y de la tercera edad.

loans.use: To purchase candy, cookies, oranges, churros and other sweets.

texts.en:
For the last two years, Juana has sold underwear and jewellery from catalogues: she is married and has two small children aged 4 and 8. She started her own underwear and jewellery business because she wanted to be independent and to contribute to household expenses, especially as her husband earns a relatively small salary which isn’t sufficient to meet all the family’s needs.

Juana wants to increase her number of customers, and to do this she needs to ensure she has a good range of products. For this reason, she’s asking for a loan of $150 dollars which she will use to purchase stock: thanks to recommendations from family and friends she already knows of many more potential customers. Please contribute to the growth of this business and help Juana.

Translated from Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Desde hace dos años, Juana se dedica a la venta de ropa interior y joyería por catálogo, ella es casada y tiene dos pequeños hijos de 4 y 8 años. Inició su propio negocio con la venta de ropa interior y joyería porque a ella le gusta ser independiente y contribuir con las obligaciones de su hogar, ya que su esposo tiene un sueldo relativamente bajo, insuficiente para satisfacer las necesidades de su familia.

Juana quiere incrementar su número de clientes, para hacerlo necesita contar con un buen surtido de sus productos, para lo que solicita un préstamo por $ 150 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía, gracias a la recomendación de sus familiares y amigos ha logrado conocer a muchos posibles compradores. Contribuye al crecimiento de este negocio y ayuda a Juana.

Translated from Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Thelma is married, and has two children who are also already married. Her husband is a agricultural day-labourer. There were occasion where he was without work and the family suffered serious economic difficulties. Faced with this, Thelma decided to start-up her own business 6 years ago, selling snacks, soft drinks and making tamales. Little by little, her business has grown, and she now has a small shop.

Now, Thelma needs a loan of $550 dollars which she will use to purchase more stock to offer a better variety of products to her clients and in order to better adapt the area in which she makes tamales, because she wants to increase production. The well-being of this family is in your hands: they thank-you sincerely for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Thelma es casada y tiene dos hijos que ya están casados. Su esposo es jornalero y trabaja en las labores del campo, en ocasiones se quedaba sin trabajo y la familia pasaba por graves problemas económicos, ante esta necesidad, Thelma decidió iniciar su propio negocio, hace seis años, vendiendo frituras, refrescos y haciendo tamales, poco a poco ha ido surtiendo mejor su negocio, ahora tiene una pequeña tienda.

En estos momentos, Thelma necesita de un préstamo por $ 550 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para ofrecer mejor variedad a sus clientes y para acondicionar mejor el lugar en el que se dedica la elaboración de los tamales, porque quiere incrementar su producción. En tus manos esta el bienestar de esta familia, ellos te agradecen sinceramente tu ayuda.

Alicia works with her husband to make suits and overcoats for men with cloth from local markets. They sell their garments during the mornings, which is traditional in Bolivia, and this serves as their source of income to provide for the family. They live with their two children and even their parents in a home they own in the Tejar area of La Paz.

The loan will be used to purchase cloth and carry out the work. This is the fourth loan Alicia has requested, and her credit history makes her an excellent candidate to receive another loan to help increase her family's income.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Alicia trabaja con su esposo en la confección de trajes y abrigos para varones en telas de paño adquiridas en mercados locales, prendas que son comercializadas en la feria de la Tumusla Ciudad de La Paz por las mañanas ( este trabajo se denomina en Bolivia “mañaneras”), constituyendo su fuente de ingreso para la manutención de su familia. Viven con sus dos hijos dependientes aun de los padres en casa propia en la zona Tejar de la Ciudad de La Paz. (ladera Norte). El crédito esta destinado a la compra de materia prima (tela), para efectuar su trabajo, o sea insumos primarios.Este es el cuarto crédito que solicita a Impro, su buen antecedente le permite acceder a otro crédito para mejorar sus ingresos familiares.

Vladimir lives with his wife, Sandra Zeballos, and their four children in his home in El Alto. Vladimir works as a security guard for a customs company at El Alto International Airport. With prior loans, he's been able to add four rooms to his home. But the main wall facing the street is deteriorating and dangerous, and it can let in water when it is raining. The loan Vladimir is requesting would be used to replace the current adobe and construct a wall of brick and mortar. This is the fourth loan he has requested, and his credit history makes him an excellent candidate.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Vladimir vive con su esposa, la señora Sandra Zeballos y cuatro hijos de 16,14 y 12 año, en su vivienda de Villa Tunari en la ciudad de El Alto. Vladimir trabaja como oficial de seguridad en una empresa aduanera del Aeropuerto internacional de El Alto, del Departamento de La Paz. Con créditos de Impro otorgados en gestiones pasadas pudo efectuar la conclusión de cuatro habitaciones, las cuales son ocupadas por su familia, pero el muro principal de la vivienda que queda hacia la calle, se encuentra en total deterioro y es peligroso, por cuanto corre el riesgo de caer con las lluvias. El destino del crédito es para cambiar el muro de adobe existente y construir un muro de ladrillo y cemento. Es la cuarta ocasión que solicita un préstamo en nuestra institución, y su rendimiento y puntualidad demuestran un comportamiento crediticio bueno.

payments.comment: Vladimir would like to apply for another loan, so he is paying this first loan off today

texts.en:
Domingo lives with his wife, Felipa Tambo, and their two children, in a small home that they own on the west side of La Paz. He has worked for a textile business in the city for the past 10 years, and his wife sells juices at a sales post in a local market. Their brick-and-adobe home has four rooms with a small terrace that has been difficult to construct. The loan Domingo is requesting would be used to finish the terrace as well as put on a roof and close off an area on the ground floor to be used as his son's bedroom. This is the first loan Domingo has requested, and his background shows he would be able to fulfill it.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Domingo H. vive en compañía de su esposa, la señora Felipa Tambo y sus dos hijos aun dependientes, en una pequeña casa de su propiedad en la zona 8 de Diciembre, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, Trabaja como empleado en una empresa textil de La Paz desde hace diez años y su esposa se dedica a la venta de jugos en un puesto de venta en un mercado de su zona. La vivienda del señor Domingo H. cuenta con cuatro habitaciones de adobe y ladrillo y con una pequeña terraza cuya construcción se encuentra en obra gruesa. El destino del crédito es para concluir dicha terraza y realizar el techado y cerramiento en planta baja para contar así con un dormitorio para su hijo. El señor Domingo H. será beneficiado por primera vez con un crédito en nuestra institución, y la evaluación socioeconómica muestra que tienen capacidad para cubrir su obligación crediticia.

This entrepreneur is the father of a big family of four children, two of whom are in schools. He has a small restaurant in the Kirkuk market. Two young men work with him in the restaurant.

This is his first loan from MFI in Kirkuk. He wants to develop his shop and buy chairs with tables to seat more customers. Also he wants to hire an unemployed person and pay him a daily wage. As he said, " I was unemployed for two years. I was suffering so if I can, I will hire all the unemployed in Kirkuk in my restaurant." He works hard and is full of confidence that he is capable of developing his business and enhancing his living standards.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan. Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

This entrepreneur is a 55-year-old mother of three girls. Her husband died two years ago in a terrorist attack in Kirkuk. In 2005 she bought a sewing machine to work in the home and earn money for her family. At sunrise every day she starts her work full of energy, despite all the hard and difficult circumstances that she is facing. Shinvested her knowledge of the market, and she is determined in innovating new methods of work.

She now seeks a loan of $1200 from Al-Aman. She hopes to get larger loans and build a credit history in the future, which will enable her to develop her small business. The purpose of this loan is to buy a new and modern sewing machine.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan. Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.name: Muslum

texts.en: Bialov Muslum Mahmud Ogli is a local farmer in Saatli region. He has a family of 4 members. Intolerable living conditions made him start his business, animal breeding, in 2003. Now, to expand his business, he needs to buy another sheep. Therefore, he applied to Aqroinvest CU for a 700 USD loan.

loans.use: To expand his business he needs to buy another sheep.

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en:
J. Saleh Pirverdi Ogli lives in Imishli region, Yalavaj village. He is the father of 3 children. He is the only breadwinner in his family.

His financial situation caused him to start his trading business in 2004. For the present time, Saleh runs his own shop. According to him, he enjoys his business and is always glad to serve clients. However, recently he has faced some hardships in his trading business. He needs 1200 USD that will be used to as follows: $350 he will use to pay the rent , $300 to buy shop windows and $550 to buy a new consignment of goods.

loans.use: Pay rent, buy windows and inventory

loans.name: Akber

texts.en:
Ahmeodov Akber Ali Ogli is a 68-year-old refugee living in Bilasuvar region. He has 7 children and a wife. In 1989, his family and he were forced to leave his house, his farm and calm village life in Zangelan region and run. Having been re-located in Bilasuvar region, in 1990 he commenced his business, animal breeding.

He has applied for a loan of 1200 USD. He needs to buy two cows and expand his business to support his big family who are living in very poor conditions.

loans.use: He needs to buy two cows and expand his business.

loans.name: Celina Amador

texts.en:
I have been making and selling tortillas for four years. I have two school-aged children. My best customers are my neighbors.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer

Mi negocio es la elaboracion y venta de tortillas desde hace 4 años. tengo dos hijos en edad escolar y mis mejores clientes son mis vecinos de la comunidad

loans.use: To buy corn for making tortillas

loans.name: Wendy Patricia

texts.en:
I sell cosmetics, perfume and clothing. I have been in business four years. With the income I earn I can help support my family. I run the business out of my home, selling to people who work in offices.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer

Yo me dedico a la venta de comesticos , perfumes y ropa. este negocio lo tengo hace 4 años. Con los ingresos de venta le ayudo a mi familia. el negocio lo tengo en mi casa. Mis clientas son personas que trabajan en oficina.

loans.use: To purchase clothing, cosmetics and perfume.

texts.en:
Nora is 30 years old and is from Monterrey. She is a divorced woman who has 4 children. She began to sell beauty products when she divorced, because she was not able to support her family with her salary. While she was working in a factory she realised she could sell products and make more money. So she bought some beauty products and started-up her business.

Now, Nora needs your help, because she needs a loan of USD$ 750 to get more beauty products, so that she can attract new customers and sell more in order to give her children a better life.

loans.name: Ana Luisa

texts.en:
I have had my business for four years. I sell coffee, soft drinks, rice, beans, dairy products, candies, bread, etc. The business is located in my house. I sell to the whole community. Now I need to buy more products so that I can provide better service to my customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo 4 años de tener mi negocio. Mis ventas son; cafe, refrescos, arroz, frijoles, lacteos, confites, pan. etc. este negocio lo tengo hubicado en mi casa. Yo le vengo a toda la cominidad, ahora nesecito comprar mas producto para darles un mejor servico a mis clientes.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks, coffe, rice, sugar, and meats

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

texts.en:
I have had this business for three years. I make and sell corn tamales and I also cook corn-on-the-cob, to which I add cheese or sour cream, however the customer requests. This business provides what I need to help with my children’s schooling.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo 3 años de tener este negocio, yo me dedico hacer tamalitos de elote y cocinar elotes a los cuales les agrego queso o mantequilla, como lo pida el cliente. este degocio me da mis gastos para ayudar a los estudios de mis hijos.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

texts.en:
Bertha Alicia is a woman who works very hard. She is married with 3 children (ages 5, 6, and 15) who are currently in school. Her husband works as a security guard; however, his salary is insufficient to sustain household and educational expenses. Bertha decided to start her own business two years ago. She started selling only baby diapers and then reinvested her profits. Now her shop maintains a greater assortment, and she counts on many clients.

To continue growing, Bertha requests a loan of $250 dollars which she will use to buy a refrigerator. The fridge will serve to further increase the variety of products and allow for the best possible customer service. She will repay the amount of her loan within 1-2 months. This will be a vital part of the growth of her business, and Bertha and her family are grateful for your trust and support.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Bertha Alicia es una mujer muy trabajadora, es casada y tiene tres hijos D. 5, 6 y 15 años D. edad, que se encuentran estudiando, su esposo trabaja como empleado D. seguridad pero el salario que logra obtener es insuficiente para poder cubrir los gastos D. su hogar y D. L. escueL. D. sus hijos, Berta decidió iniciar su propio negocio hace dos años, comenzó vendiendo solamente pañales y reinvirtió sus utilidades, ahora tiene una tienda con mayor surtido y cuenta con muchos clientes.

Para continuar creciendo, Bertha necesita un préstamo por $ 250 dólares que utilizará en L. compra D. un refrigerador, éste le servirá para incrementar su variedad D. productos y ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes, elL. se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en un lapso D. 1 a 2 meses. Se parte importante en el crecimiento D. este negocio, Bertha y su familia agradecen tu confianza y apoyo.

Ms Bertha is a widow of five years with four children who are financially dependent on her. In the past, her husband had a place where he sold traditional Mexican sweets. Bertha continued the business after his death. She also incorporated other goods, like pottery, cosmetics, etc., for sale. Her youngest child of 12 helps with the business, and together they have been able to move the business forward.

Lamentably, Bertha’s mother died recently, and Bertha spent her savings on the funeral. Now she requests a loan of $325 dollars to stock up on pottery and continue with her work. You can help improve this family’s way of life. They appreciate your generosity and support.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Bertha es viuda desde hace cinco años, tiene cuatro hijos que dependen económicamente de ella. Anteriormente su esposo tenía un local en el que vendía dulces típicos mexicanos, y ella continuó con el negocio, después fue incorporando la venta de otros bienes como alfarería, coronas para difuntos, cosméticos, etc. En el negocio recibe la ayuda de su hija menor, de 12 años de edad, y juntas han logrado sacarlo adelante.

Lamentablemente, hace poco falleció la madre de Bertha y gastó sus ahorros en el funeral, ahora necesita un préstamo por $ 325 dólares para surtirse de alfarería y poder continuar con su trabajo. Tú puedes ayudar a mejorar las condiciones de vida de esta familia, ellas agradecen tu generosidad y apoyo.

Maria de los Ángeles is married and has three children. When she married, she had to give up her job, and so to help her husband with the bills she decided to start her own business selling stationery and gifts from her home. She began with very few products but little by little, with the help of her eldest daughter who works in the shop after school, the stationery shop has been expanding and they have increased the variety of products on offer.

Now, Maria needs a loan of $750 dollars in order to fix the business’ photocopying machine and buy more school stationery items, as these are the most popular products on offer. You can improve the living conditions of this family and contribute to the growth of this building, don’t hesitate!

Translated from Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria de los Ángeles es casada y tiene tres hijos. La despidieron de su trabajo cuando se casó y para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos decidió iniciar su propio negocio con la venta de papelería y regalos, en su domicilio, empezó con muy pocos productos, pero poco a poco y con la ayuda de su hija mayor, que atiende el negocio después de su escuela, la papelería ha estado creciendo e incrementando la variedad de productos que ofrece.

En estos momentos, Maria necesita un crédito por $ 750 dólares con el que podrá arreglar la máquina copiadora que tiene en el negocio y comprar artículos escolares para tener un mejor surtido de estos productos que son los de mayor demanda. Tú puedes mejorar las condiciones de vida de esta familia y contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio, no lo dudes más.

loans.name: Maria Del Socorro

texts.en:
Ms Maria del Socorro is a widow of eleven years. She has worked every day to motivate her seven children, five of which are in school. She started cleaning houses for an income that would allow her to support her family. Then she started studying cosmetology, and, with great effort, after eight years was able to open her own beauty salon where she works arduously so that her children have the ability to finish school.

Maria is a very responsible and hard-working person. She wants her business to grow, and therefore requests a loan of $275 dollars to invest in the purchase of a washing basin to wash hair. With this, she can improve her service to her customers. Maria’s family appreciates your generosity and support in the growth of this business and betterment of this family’s way of life.
