His wife took her 2nd cycle group loan and her husband bought all the materials that he needed for his shop. Now his wife wants to take anther loan for her husband so that he can buy new machines and solve the economic problems of his family. He would like to make a good future for his family and he is happy now.

Rofi and his family live in a beautiful place inTajikistan – village Chorku. It means “four mountains” and in fact his house is among mountains. It happened so that in the last years he decided to be engaged in trade. He chose household goods such as: teapots, plates, glasses, buckets and so on as merchandise to sell and he succeeded.

Nowadays his business makes enough profit to cover living expenses. At present he has a permanent place in the central market, where he trades every day. He took a loan of $ 650 and spent it for a new assortment of goods. This gave him additional income. Now he would like to get another loan, as he is sure he will manage it successfully.

Oishahon has been trading at the central market for several years. Her business is small, but it gives good income. In summer she and her daughters deal with processing fruits and vegetables. Vegetables and fruits are cheap at that time and the cost of canned ones is low. In the winter period, all these things are brought to the market and income from the sale is enough for their life, more or less.

Near to spring, canned products have been sold out and the time of young spring greens begins. At this time, Oishahon goes over to selling greens. Her daughters help her.

She spent the first loan she received ($ 300) to buy vegetables for sale. She is working seriously with MicroInvest and intends to continue working with them.

Oishahon hopes to receive another loan and spend it to buy glass jars for the new season of processing fruits and vegetables.

Although she is elderly, Mukaddas continues to go to market for trade. Her husband is retired. Her sons went to Russia to earn money, but they had no permanent place to work and there is lack of money in the family.

Mukaddas' husband, daughter-in-law, and three little grandchildren live together with her. She goes to buy goods to the market at Kokand, Uzbekistan, 55 km away from her house. She has no problem crossing the border, and goods are cheaper there. She has been receiving loans from MicroInvest already for half a year. She uses the loan for replenishment of her goods.

The winter has ended now but Mukaddas still has winter clothes among her goods, which she plans to sell next season. Therefore she needs additional capital to purchase a spring-summer assortment. Also the new loan of $800 will be used for improvement of her work place conditions.

Starting from childhood looking after his family's livestock, Sulton dreamt about his own farm. His father instilled love of animals in all his children and nowadays they are all in business with livestock raising and fattening. Together with his elder brother, Sultan would go to all the neighboring markets to buy bulls and cows.

A year ago Sulton got his first loan of $300. Having added his own money, he bought 12 young bulls of the same breed for himself from neighboring Kyrgystan. As it turned out, the bulls were of tribal breed, so after 4 months of their sale, it turned out that Sulton had doubled the money he had received. From that time on, he constantly buys and raises this breed. All his family is engaged in his business. Sulton's son already knows all the details of this business and helps his father.

Now Sulton is planning to modernize and expand the place he keeps his animals. He needs $ 1200 to do this. Sulton will add his savings and prepare the place, as he intends to expand his business even more.

Mena lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives with all members of her family. She wants to help her husband who has a fuel shop. His wife took her 2nd cycle group loan for her husband that he could buy more fuel and attract a lot of clients. Now his wife wants to take anther loan for her husband so that he can expand his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Leah would like to buy 300 chickens and chicken feed.

texts.en: Fazel Ahamad lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is uneducated and he has a workshop for repairing cars. He took his 2nd cycle individual loan and opened this shop and now he wants to take anther loan to buy new machines and expand his business to make a good monthly income for his family and send his children to a good school to became educated. He is very happy with this loan.

M. Haraf lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single and uneducated. He opened a retail shop and he needs money to purchase inventory. He wants to take an individual loan to buy milk, Pepsi Cola, powder, boxes of chocolates and packets of sweets. He is truing to be a great business dealer to make bright future for himself. He is happy now and he would like to thank AFSG for supporting him.

loans.name: Fahima

texts.en: Fahima lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives with all members of her family. She is a widow; her husband died during the war against the Taliban. She tries to help her family. She has a son who has a shoe shop. His mother took her 4th cycle group loan and he bought all the new designs of shoes and made a good business. Now his mothers wants to take anther loan so that he can make good commerce and be one of the good business dealers in future.

loans.use: To buy new designs of shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 20 bags of cereals and ground nuts.

texts.en: Mrusal lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a widow; her husband died of cancer. She always wants to make a good life for her children. One of her sons is a coil seller. He has a shop and his mother took her 4th cycle group loan so that he could expand his business and make a good income for his family. Now his mother wants to take anther loan so that her son can buy more coil to attract more clients to be a good business dealer in the future. He would like to thank his mother for helping him.

Sailah lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives with all members of her family. Her husband is jobless because he is sick. They have a son who has a bicycle shop and he also sells bicycle kits. His mother took her 4th cycle group loan so that he could buy more kits for his shop to make good business for his family. Now his mother wants to take anther loan so that he can buy extra materials to expand his business. Now he is very happy and he would like to thank AFSG.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en: Habiba lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives with all members of her family. She wants to help her son who has a shoe shop and also a bicycle shop. She took her 4th cycle group loan so that he could buy all new materials and new designs of shoes. Now she wants to take anther loan so that her son can buy bicycle tools to expand both his businesses and make a good income for his family and take care of his father. He is very happy that he can support his family.

loans.use: To buy new designs of shoes and extra materials

texts.en:
Angel is a carpenter, he builds wooden furniture and sells them in the markets of la Paz. He has three sons that depend on him; he works independently so his main source of income is his job. He lives in Villa Dolores, located in El Alto city, and his workshop is in Santa Rita which is an area of La Paz. He creates job opportunities by employing an assistant at the workshop and temporary workers, depending on the magnitude of the projects. The loan would be used to buy raw material (wood). This is the 13th time Angel has applied for a loan with Impro and his good credit makes him eligible for another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Angel, es carpintero elabora muebles de madera para comercializarlo en las ferias de La Paz, tiene tres hijos que dependen de él, y trabaja en forma independiente por lo que su actividad es su principal fuente de ingresos con que mantiene a su familia. Vive en la Zona de villa Dolores de la Ciudad de El Alto y su taller está ubicado en la Zona Santa Rita de la Ciudad de La Paz. Genera fuentes de empleo ya que trabaja con un ayudante permanente en el talle, y suele contratar personal eventual de acuerdo a la magnitud del trabajo que efectúe. E crédito será destinado para la compra de materia prima (madera). Es el decimotercer crédito con Impro, los buenos antecedentes que tiene le faculta a acceder a otro préstamo.

Jesua and her husband Felix have a small cheese factory and they sell their product at wholesale quantities in La Paz. They have 3 sons ages 20,18 and 16, all three help take care of the milk producing cattle. The family lives in Achica Baja community, located in Ingavi province, La Paz (2 hours away from La Paz city). Jesua has one employee that helps making cheese. She will use the loan to buy a milk cow to produce more cheese, with which she'll be able to earn more income. This is the first time she has applied for a loan and our evaluation determined that she is eligible for it.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Jesua, trabaja con su esposo Felix tienen un pequeño taller de elaboración de queso de leche de vaca, comercializan al por mayor en la ciudad La Paz, tiene tres hijos de 20, 18 y 16 de edad, los mismos que ayudan con el cuidado de las vacas que producen leche. Viven en la Comunidad Achica Baja de la Provincia Ingavi de La Paz (a 2 horas de la Ciudad d La Paz). Tiene un empleado que ayuda con la elaboración del queso. El destino del crédito es para la compra de una vaca lechera que le permitirá producir mayor cantidad de queso, lo cual le redituará un mayor ingreso. Es el primer crédito que solicita y la evaluación que se realizo lo califica para otorgarle el préstamo que solicita.

Freddy has a tailoring shop in 14 de Septiembre area in La Paz, a very busy district and suitable for his trade. He works alone and when he has too many orders, he hires extra tailors to help him and he pays them for each finished suit. He designs and creates each suit individually because each one is hand-made, custom fit and to the customer's liking. Freddy also alters men's and women's clothes. It is his first time applying for a loan and the money will be used to buy basic material (fabric, zippers, threads, buttons.) His work and the conditions of his workshop qualifies him to apply for a loan, because he has experience in his business and a good amount of clients, which means he can generate enough income to repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Freddy tiene un taller de sastrería en la Zona 14 de Septiembre de la ciudad de La Paz, la cual es una zona muy comercial y adecuada a la actividad que tiene. Trabaja solo y cuando tiene muchos pedidos contrata a sastres – ayudantes a quienes paga por traje terminado. La elaboración de trajes es a solicitud individual ya que todo trabajo que realiza es a medida, a mano y a gusto del cliente. También realiza arreglos y composturas de trajes de mujer o varón. Es la primera vez que solicita crédito. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de materia prima (Tela, forro, cierre, hilo, botones) Su trabajo y las instalaciones de su taller le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio y además mucha clientela, lo cual le da ingresos para cubrir el préstamo.

Aydin is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) living in the Bilasuvar district of Azerbaijan. He is 57 years old, married, and has 5 children. He started his business in 1990 with small loans from friends. After that, using the revenues from his business, he was able to expand his business slightly and improve the living condition of his family. He has applied to Agroinvest to borrow $500 to further expand his business by purchasing an additional animal.

Beatriz has a grocery store where she also serves snacks during tea time and provides phone call services. She lives with her mom, grandmother and three younger brothers ages 18, 12 and 6, and she supports them with her income. The house they live in is their gradmother's. The loan would be used to buy more merchandise for her store and to improve her income. It is Beatriz's second loan and her good credit history qualifies her for another loan to better her income and support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Beatriz tiene una tienda de abarrotes, servicio de té y atención de llamadas telefónica móvil al publico, vive con su madre, abuela y tres hermanos menores de 18, 12 y 6 años, y con los ingresos que genera ayuda a la manutención de la familia. La Casa donde viven es de su abuela. El destino del crédito es para incrementar mercadería de la tienda, para mejorar sus ingresos. Es el segundo crédito, su buen antecedente crediticio le permite acceder a otro crédito para mejorar sus ingresos familiares, de esa forma ayudar en la familia.

payments.comment: Loan Pay off.  Beatriz is applying for a new loan.

texts.en: Alasgar is an internal refugee from Nagorno Karabakh. He is 45 years old, married, and has 4 children. He fled to the Bilasuvar district of Azerbaijan in 1993. In 1994, he started his private animal breeding/sale business with a little money at his own expense. With this business, he started to make a living for his family little-by-little. After some time, he  expanded his business to meet the greater needs of his family and to make the business financially sustainable. Now, he has applied for an Agroinvest loan of $500 to buy a cow and further expand his business.

Wilde makes cheeses with the help of his wife and sells them in busy markets in El Alto City. He also builds furniture out of metal. Both activities are his main sources of income to support his 2 sons, ages 8 and 3. He lives in Achica Baja community in Ingavi province, located in La Paz (2 hours away from La Paz city). Wilde will use the loan to buy another milk cow, so he can make more cheeses. This is Wilde's second loan; due to his duly and timely payments, he is qualified to request for another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Wilde, trabajo con su esposa en la elaboración de quesos de leche de vaca para comercializarlos en las ferias populares de la Ciudad de El Alto, también se dedica a la Cerrajería (Muebles de Metal), estas actividades son sus principales fuentes de ingresos para la manutención de sus 2 hijos de 8 y 3 año de edad. Vive en la Comunidad Achica Baja de la Provincia Ingavi de La Paz (a 2 horas de la Ciudad d La Paz) El destino del crédito es para la compra de vaca lechera que le ayudara a producir mayor cantidad de queso. Es el segundo crédito, el buen comportamiento de pago del anterior le faculta para solicitar otro préstamo.

Sonia makes cheese from cow milk and sells it in the market of Viacha (a rural area an hour and a half away from La Paz), while her husband is a baker. These two activities are their main sources of income to support their 6 children, ages 12, 10, 8, 5, 3 and 1. Sonia an her family live in Achica Baja community on Ingavi province, La Paz (2 hours away from la Paz city). The loan will be used to buy a milk cow so Sonia can make more cheese. It is her second loan and her good credit with our institution allows her to take out further loans, which will help her earn more income and improve her family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Sonia, elabora queso de leche de vaca para comercializarlos en la feria de Viacha (localidad rural a 1 hora y media de la ciudad de La Paz), el esposo es panadero, y estas son sus actividades principales generadoras de ingresos para la manutención de sus 6 hijos de 12, 10, 8, 5, 3 y 1 año de edad. Vive en la Comunidad Achica Baja de la Provincia Ingavi de La Paz (a 2 horas de la Ciudad de La Paz) El crédito será destinado para la comprar una vaca lechera, lo que le permitirá incrementar su producción de queso. Es el segundo crédito, los buenos antecedentes que tiene en nuestra institución le permiten acceder a otro préstamo que le ayudara a subir sus ingresos y mejorar las condiciones de vida familiares.

loans.name: Nam

texts.en: Nam is 47 years old. Her husband has died. She lives with her 3 sons; the youngest is 16 and the oldest is 24. All her sons quit school to find work and bring in some income. Yet, their employment is not stable. Their income is only $6 per person/month. Nam wants to get a non-profit loan of $75 so that she can grow sugar cane and raise fish in her field. Nam will repay monthly.

loans.use: To improve the sugar cane field.

loans.name: Ligia

texts.en:
Ligia has 12 years of experience with her business. She started as a school bus chauffer. Then, she managed a grocery store that was far from her home. Noting that this required a lot of travel time, she decided to start a business in her home and saved money to do this start-up. So far, she's been running the business from her home for 2 years and it is going very well. She works every day from 6am to 11pm. Her husband helps a lot with the business as well.

Ligia requires credit in order to enhance her business line with more products such as meats and sausages. She would like to buy an oven in order to start making breads as well.

Ligia is married and has 3 children who are all studying. During their spare moments, they help with the store as well. Her husband is a chauffer and uses his own car to chauffer school children. In addition to running her store, Ligia is studying baking in a course run by a company called Empresa. She hopes to finish the course and then be able to start making fresh bread products to sell.

Ligia tiene una experiencia de 12 años con su actividad. Se inicio siendo chofer de expreso escolar. Pone un local de venta de víveres lejos de su domicilio. Viendo que esto le significaba demasiado tiempo decide con sus ahorros adecuar su hogar para poner su negocio en casa. Actualmente tiene ya 2 años en su domicilio y le ha ido muy bien. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 11 p.m. Su esposo le ayuda mucho en su negocio siendo una ayuda enorme para ella.

Ligia desea el crédito para poder surtir su negocio con otra clase de productos como lo son las carnes y embutidos. Además ella ya cuenta con un horno y muy pronto comenzara a producir panes.

Ligia es casada. Tiene 3 hijos los cuales estudian y en sus ratos libres le ayudan con la atención de la tienda. Su esposo trabaja de chofer en carro propio haciendo expreso escolar. Ligia además de su trabajo ella también estudia panadería en nuestros cursos que da la Empresa. Su deseo es poder terminar su curso y de esta manera con el conocimiento comenzar a trabajar en la elaboración de productos de panadería.

loans.use: Augment her business with new products

texts.en:
Veronica has 2 years of experience running her own business. She started when she was young helping her mother with her business of selling fruits. She really enjoyed the work and little by little she was able to save money. Using this capital, she decided to start selling chickens. She works every day of the week from 5am until 2pm. Sometimes, she has a lot of demand right into the late afternoon.

Veronica requires credit to buy more chickens since the demand is rising. Additionally, she wants to start raising her own chickens in order to keep her costs low. That will also bring her more earnings.

Veronica is a single mother. She is 30 years old and has 2 children who are studying. Her business is based in her mother's home, which helps a lot. She also has a fruit stand at a local market near her home. When she cannot attend the stand, her father is there. She hopes to be able to locate her fruit stand business in her mothers home one day. There is good demand for her product and she is recognized in the neighborhood for her business acumen.

Verónica tiene una experiencia de 2 años con su negocio propio. Se inicio desde muy pequeña ayudándole a su mama en el negocio de venta de frutas. Gusto mucho el trabajo que ella poco a poco con sus ahorros decide comenzar con un capital pequeño para vender pollos. Trabaja todos los días de la semana desde las 5 a.m. hasta las 2 p.m. . En algunos casos hasta la noche cuando tiene demasiada demanda.

Verónica desea el crédito para comprar mas pollos ya que su demanda va en aumento. Además desea ella misma comenzar a criar sus propios pollos y de esta manera sus costos van ha ser mas baratos. Lo que le dejaría mayor ganancia.

Verónica es madre soltera. Tiene 30 años. Dos hijos los que estudian. Su negocio lo tiene en casa de su mama la que la apoya bastante. Además tiene un puesto de frutas en un mercado cerca de su domicilio. El que cuando ella no puede atenderlo lo hace su papa. Su deseo es poder adecuar un local en casa de su mama para poner el negocio de las frutas. Tiene una buena demanda su producto y es bien reconocida en el sector.

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela has 6 years of experience running her business. She started it using some savings that earned from selling plastic goods. She started sales just by walking through neighborhoods. She got a loan from the bank and then was able to start her business out of her home. Little by little, she was able to make money and buy house goods and was able to provide basic products to sell in her business. Currently at her store she also sell jewelry, clothing and children's clothes. She works every day of the week from 7am to 10 pm.

Adela wants credit in order to augment the number of products sold in her store. She would also like to buy more clothes and jewelry to sell.

Adela is a single mother. She is 29 years old. She has 3 children who are all attending school. She has been seperated for 3 years, and she has pushed herself and children to continue to work hard and achieve. Her work has allowed her to support her children's education. Her hope is to have a store full of products which will increase her profit and help her family.

Adela tiene una experiencia de 6 años con su negocio. Se inicio con unos ahorros que tenia comprando artículos plásticos. Comienza a vender ambulante por su sector. Hace un préstamo al banco y con este adecua su casa poniendo un local. Poco a poco con sus ganancias comienza a comprar víveres y de esta manera lograr surtir su local con productos de primera necesidad. Actualmente en su local también vende productos de bisutería y ropa interior y de niños. Trabaja todos los días de la semana desde las 7 a.m. hasta las 10 p.m.

Adela desea el crédito para surtir en su tienda en víveres. Además desea comprar más ropa y productos de bisutería.

Adela es madre soltera. Tiene 29 años. Tres hijos los que estudian. Esta separada 3 años de su esposo lo que ha ella la ha impulsado a seguir adelante por sus hijos y con sus hijos. Su trabajo le ha ayudado para darles una buena educación a sus hijos y también surtir su negocio. Su deseo es tener su tienda llena de productos lo que le dejara más ganancia.

loans.use: Augment her business with home products, clothes and jewelry

texts.en:
Don Miguel is a vendor who has recently moved to the city after living most of his life in rural Ecuador in a town named Quevedo. Although Don Miguel and his wife are older they refuse to be burdens to their children who do not make much money. They purchase certain fruits and vegetables at wholesale prices from his town and take them into the city to be sold. They also bring goods from the city back to Quevedo where they can resell them for a profit. He travels back and forth about twice a week and is happy with his business.

This is Miguel's second loan with Kiva and Mifex. WIth the first loan he was able to invest in a variety of household items that he resold in his hometown. The initial investment allowed him to permanently increase his capital reserves so he could bring in more profits consistently as he was able to purchase more products as investments. He ended up investing in a small plot of oranges in his hometown. He is still waiting to cultivate the profits, but he is very optimistic about this particular investment. Miguel was also able to improve his home by building a bathroom with plumbing inside his home when previously he only had an outhouse. He plans to invest his second loan just as the first one, in household products to resell in his hometown. He wants to continue to improve his home with the profits, beginning by changing the walls which are currently made out of bamboo.

Translated by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Maria has a stand where she sells fresh fruit and juice. Maria used to sell vegetables from her stand, but because profits were not sufficient she and her husband decided to try something different. After being forced to move from their old location because they did not have government permits, they moved the stand to a location closer to their home. Maria and her husband prepare the juice and fruit salad in the mornings. While Maria stays at the stand, her husband travels around the community in his tricycle cart selling the fresh juice and fruit salad.

This is Maria's second loan with Kiva and Mifex. With her first loan she purchased new types of utensils and appliances. She purchased a new blender, sandwich maker and juicer. Although she had planned to invest in a new cart, when time came to make the investment she decided it was a wiser move to reinforce her current stand before venturing into a new point of sale. She is happy with the decision now that she can work much more efficiently and her client base has increased. Her second loan will be directed towards making the investment in a new cart as she planned before.

Maria is 35 years old, married, and has 3 children. They live in her husband’s family's house where they pay rent. Maria’s goal is to save up enough money to buy herself and her children a home.

Translated by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Rosita has a business selling gifts, jewelry, household plastic articles such as jugs, glass figurines, slippers, garbage cans, clothing hangers, rope and others. Her businesses has been located in her home for the last ten years. She began with very little money that she saved through a lot of effort. She tends to her clients from 6 am until 10 pm every day of the week.

Rosita needs a loan in order to buy school supplies and gifts. For the school year her clients have requested supplies from class lists.

Rosita is 39 years old and has two sons that are both students. With this loan, Rosita will invest in more products that will provide greater profits for her and will also be in accordance with client requests and her family's needs.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Rosita tiene su negocio de venta de regalos, bisuterías, artículos plásticos para el hogar como: Lavacaras, jarras, juegos de vasos y tazas plásticas, zapatillas, tachos de basuras, cestos de ropa, ropa y otros. Ubicado en su domicilio desde hace 10 años. Se inicio con pequeños ahorros que ella ahorro con mucho esfuerzo. Atiende a sus clientes desde las 6: AM a 22: PM todos los días de la semana.

Rosita necesita de un préstamo para poder comprar útiles escolares, regalos. Por ser época escolar sus clientes le han solicitado que les provea de las listas de útiles escolares.

Rosita tiene 39 años 2 hijos los mismos que están estudiando. Rosita indica que con el préstamo invertirá en mas productos que le proporcionara mayores ingresos y a su vez cumplirá con la demanda de sus clientes y el bienestar de su familia

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Silvia has operated her beauty salon for six years, her husband having helped her with a small amount of start-up capital. Silvia enjoys this work, attending to her customers in her own home. She cuts hair and gives manicures, pedicures and facials. She opens from 9:00AM to noon and from 2:00 to 8:00 in the afternoon. Silvia would like financing to redecorate her beauty salon and to buy some propane tanks. She previously retailed propane and would like to restart that business in addition to the salon. Silvia is 39 years old and has 3 children, two of them in school. Her husband drives a municipal bus. Silvia is confident that with this loan she will be able to realize her dreams, to increase her income and continue to earn a livelihood.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Silvia tiene su negocio desde hace 6 años su esposo la apoyo con pequeño capital para dar inicio a su negocio de gabinete. Silvia indica que le gusta esta actividad y atiende en su casa en las tardes a sus clientes. Ella realiza cortes de cabello, limpieza de manos, pies y rostro. Silvia atiende todos los días de la semana en la mañana 9: AM a 12: PM y en las tardes desde las 14: PM a 20: PM

Silvia necesita capital para arreglar su local para de esta manera poder dar una mejor imagen del mismo. También quiere comprar mas cilindros de gas para reactivar su negocio de venta de gas que lo tenia antes.

Silvia tiene 39 años 3 hijos de los cuales 2 estudian. Esposo labora como chofer en una línea de transporte urbano. Silvia indica que tiene la confianza que con el crédito ella podrá realizar sus anhelos seguir incrementando sus ingresos y así poder seguir adecuando su vivienda y local.

loans.use: To redecorate a beauty salon and purchase propane tanks.

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.en:
Four years ago Eulalia used her small savings to start up a business selling fish. Every day, she hawks fish like bass and perch through her neighborhood from 7:00 in the morning until 10:00 at night. She would like a loan to buy more fish and to outfit a small restaurant in her home, which has unfinished floors. Eulalia used to have a restaurant but was forced to close it when she lost her lease. To open the restaurant she needs to fix her industrial stove and purchase pots and pans, as well as a few tables and plastic chairs. Eulalia is 45 and has 5 children, 3 of whom are dependent on her and attend school. She raises them by herself as her partner abandoned her some time ago. With this loan she can realize her dream of reopening her restaurant and provide for her family's livelihood.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Eulalia tiene negocio de venta de pesca desde hace 4 años. Se inicio en este negocio con ahorros propios. Ella transporta su producto en un balde y recorre pie los diferentes sectores por donde vive todos los días de la semana desde las 7: AM a 10: PM. Ofreciéndoles variedad de tipos de pescado como: Corvinas, Picudo, Mojarras y otros.

Desea el crédito para poder invertir en compra de mas pescado su demanda se ha incrementado. Eulalia tenía antes un restaurante que por motivo de adecuación de local fue cancelado su contrato de arrendamiento y tuvo que dejar ese negocio. Eulalia quiere activar ese negocio en su casa y necesita mas dinero para poder comprar ollas, arreglar cocina industrial, compra un par de mesas y sillas plásticas.

Eulalia tiene 46 años 5 hijos de los que solo están a cargo 3 que estudian. Eulalia los mantiene a sus hijos sola su compañero la abandono hace tiempo. Desea que sea considerada para un crédito y así poder cumplir su anhelo de poner su restaurante. De esta manera generara mas ingresos y podrá seguir adecuado su vivienda que esta con piso de tierra.

loans.use: To buy fish and outfit a small restaurant.

loans.name: Lorenzo

texts.en:
Lorenzo has owned this small store for over 10 years. He sells all types of food products from his shop, ranging from rice to snacks for kids. He started this business with $15 (which was worth much more in Ecuador 10 years ago) and only sold rice, sugar, oil and plantains. Although he was one of the first businesses in this area he now faces competition from other stores around him. In order to contest with these businesses Lorenzo is looking to increase and diversify his inventory with this loan. He wants to begin selling chicken, meat, sausages and eggs as well as any other products that may be in demand.

Lorenzo has already lent from Kiva and Mifex and he did great with his first loan. He invested in a variety of products just as he planned. He saw his profits and the demand in the sector increase as his prices became the most competitive. He ended up investing in a second display refrigerator in order to keep the increased inventory fresh while also being able to show it to his customers. He made some small improvements to his home, although most of the profits went to the daily necessities of his wife and family. He wants to continue to invest in products for his store as he continues to grow and provide services for the community.

Translated by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Invest in supplies for his store

loans.name: Jacinto

texts.en:
Jacinto has 15 years of experience in ironwork. He started out in construction, then learned ironworking while working for someone else. His boss later sold him some of his tools and Jacinto started up his own workshop. He works every day from 8:00 in the morning until 6:00 in the evening. He also repairs machinery for a grocery store when they call him. Jacinto will use this loan to buy the steel plates, rods and tubes he uses to make door and window grills. His business is growing and he would like to continue to provide good service to his customers. Jacinto is married and has four children, two of whom are working and help with the household expenses. Through his hard work he has been able to finish his family's small concrete home and buy a small truck which he uses for his business.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Jacinto tiene una experiencia de 15 años con su actividad. Se inicio siendo albañil. Poco a poco fue adquiriendo el conocimiento de la cerrajería ya que trabajaba para otra persona la que le enseño todo el oficio. Inclusive esta persona le vendió parte de sus herramientas de trabajo para que Jacinto comience con su propio taller. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 8 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m. Además el da mantenimiento a las maquinas de un supermercado. Actividad que la realiza cuando lo llaman.

Jacinto invertirá el crédito en la compra de materia prima como lo es planchas, varillas, tubos los que le servirán para elaborar mas puertas y ventanas. Su demanda ha crecido y por ende desea dar un mejor servicio ha sus clientes.

Jacinto es casado. Tiene 4 hijos de los cuales 2 trabajan y le ayudan en los gastos del hogar. Fruto de su trabajo ha logrado terminar su casita de cemento. Su esposa también trabaja vendiendo artículos de bisutería y cosméticos. Posee un carrito el cual lo utiliza para su trabajo.

loans.use: To buy supplies such as steel plates, rods and tubing.

loans.name: Pastora

texts.en:
Pastora has had four years of experience selling cleaning products and general supplies. She worked as a salesperson in a store selling imitation jewelry which had to close because many people had a bad impression of it. Her daughter helped her with money to start her business. She works every day of the week from 6 am until 11 pm. Even on week-ends, Pastora dedicated herself to the sale of food in the entrance area of her home.

Pastora would like this loan i order to purchas two perches/shelves to help in the display of her products. She would also like to supply her store with colas. In addition, she would like to purchase two tables to sell food on during the week-ends. The demand for her products has grown in proportion to the amount of food she has available for sale.

Pastrora is 50 years old, and has been separated from her husband for two years. She has two son and a daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Pastora tiene una experiencia de 4 años con la venta de artículos de limpieza y víveres en general. Ella trabajaba vendiendo bisutería negocio que tuvo que cerrar por que mucha gente le quedo mal. Su hija fue la persona que le ayudo con el capital para poner el negocio. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 11 p.m. También los fines de semana Pastora se dedica a la venta de comida en el portal de su casa.

Pastora desea el crédito para comprar 2 perchas que le ayudaran en la exhibición de sus productos. Y también surtir su negocio con colas. Además desea comprar 2 mesas para los fines de semana que vende comida. Su demanda esta aumentando con respecto a su comida.

Pastora tiene 50 años, esta separada de su esposo hace 2 años. Tiene 2 hijos. Su hija la mayor

loans.use: Invest in products for her store

loans.name: Ngoan

texts.en: Ngoan is 49 years old. Her husband, Buol, is 45 years old. They have 2 daughters whose ages are 20 and 15. The youngest daughter attends high school. Ngoan sells 'mam' at home and at the local market. The famiL. income is $6 per person/month.  Because her home is far from the local market, she has a problem transporting the goods to  market. She wants to get a loan of $75 to purchase a small boat for transport. She will repay monthL..

loans.use: To sell ''mam'', a traditional vietnamese food.

loans.name: Hin

texts.en:
Hin T. is 59 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Peyyeng province in Cambodia. He makes his living by growing crops and raising animals on the farm. His wife helps him on the farm and together they typically make 5 USD/day in revenue. One of their children works in a local garment factory, while the other is a blacksmith. The income they earn is contributed to the household once per month.

With part of his loan, Hin hopes to purchase additional construction tools to build a house. With the rest of his loan, Hin hopes to purchase additional seeds for his plantation. In the future, Hin would like to expand his farm by increasing the number of crops and animals to respond to the increase in his clients’ demand.

loans.use: To purchase some construction tools and some seeds for his farm.

loans.name: Uch

texts.en:
Uch S. is 43 years old. She is a mother of eight children and lives with her husband in Preyveng, Cambodia. Uch is a housewife and grows some crops on her farm. Her husband is village chief and can usually make around $4/day in revenue. One of her children, meanwhile, works at the nearby garment factory and contributes all her wages to the household. The other children are students and assist their parents with works when they leave school. Uch hopes to use the loan to purchase rice seeds to grow on her farm and the rest is used to for farming tools. 
In the future, S. wants to expand her business by owning a piece of land to grow more rice and a variety of crops .

loans.use: To buy rice seeds to grow in her field.

loans.name: Nhanh

texts.en: Nhanh is 32. Her husband, Tan, is 37. They have a son, 11, and a daughter, 2. The son is attends seventh grade at high school. Nhanh makes rice alcohol and uses rice alcohol by-products to feed her pigs. Their income is $9 per person/month. They need a loan of $75 to run this activity. They will repay monthly.

loans.use: To make rice alcohol and raise pigs.

loans.name: Badam Gul

texts.en: Badam Gul lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She lives with her husband because there sons are in other countries. She wants to help her husband who has a shop where he sells wood. Badam Gul took her 4th cycle group  loan for her husband so that he could buy more wood for his shop and expand his business and make a good monthly income. Now she wants to take anther loan for her husband to enlarge his shop to support his wife and make a better future for themselves.

loans.use: To buy more wood and enlarge the shop

loans.name: Jahn

texts.en: Jahn lives in district 1 of Kabul Afghanistan she is married and she wants to help with her son she took her 4cycle group of loan for her son he open a retail shop and try to work fast to make a good business and make good monthly income for his family and now his mothers wants to take anther loan that he buy rice.onion.milk.tea.and some other retail for shop to make his business butter than now and now he would like to thanks from AFSG.

loans.use: to buy rice.onion.milk.tea and extra things

texts.en: Shakria lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan with all members of her family. She is uneducated and her husband is a shopkeeper who has a retail shop. His wife took her 4th cycle group loan and her husband bought inventory items like rice, oil, plums, baskets, bags of nuts, pears and limes to make a good business to support his family well. Now his wife wants to take anther loan so that her husband can complete the necessary things he needs to attract more customers. He wants to be a good business dealer in the future.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en: H. Seng, 23 years old, is self-employed as a photographer and lives with his wife in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He typically makes around $5/day from the business. Seng H. hopes the loan will assist him in the purchase of a camera and film for his new photography shop.  He hopes to use the money he makes in his new shop to send his children to university.

loans.use: To purchase a camera and film

texts.en: Rabia lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is uneducated and she has good experience doing traditional embroidery. Now her granddaughter is working as an embroiderer. Rabia took her 4th cycle group loan and her granddaughter bought new embroidery machines and is making a good monthly income. Now her grandmother wants to take anther loan so that that she can buy new materials for her work and support her family and expand her business. Rabia's granddaughter would like to thank her grandmother and also AFSG.

loans.name: Iv

texts.en:
Iv M. is 43 years old and a father of four children, who live with his wife in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Iv is a mechanic and typically earns around $3/day in revenue. His wife stays at home to cook meals and look after the children. Two of his children work at the local garment factory, another is a teacher, and the last is a student.

Iv hopes to use the loan of USD 600 to purchase some mechanical tools to operate his business. In the future, he hopes that he is able to purchase vehicle oil, gasoline, tires and other products to sell due to the great demand of his clients.

loans.use: To purchase some mechanical tools to generate a business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Agnes will the loan to expand and diversify her business.

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Chorn N. is 28 years old and is a seamstress. She also sells sugar cane juice in her village, and typically makes 3 USD/day. She is a mother of one child and lives with her husband, who is a construction foreman. They both live in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. N. would like a loan of 800 USD to purchase a cart for her sugar cane juices and to purchase clothes to help run her business.  In the future, Chorn N. would like to run a tailoring business, which would help her make additional income.

loans.use: To purchase some clothes and a cart to sell sugar cane juice on the roadside.

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Malia lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is living with her husband because she got married a few months ago. Her husband has a gas shop. His wife took her 4th cycle group loan and her husband bought new canisters of gas and attracted a lot of clients. He hopes that he can expand this business more and so his wife wants to take anther loan so that her husband can enlarge his shop and make a good income for his family.

loans.use: To buy new canisters of gas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Apollo will use the loan to diversify and expand his retail business.

loans.name: Han

texts.en: Han C. is a mother of three children. She is 45 years old and lives with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is a seamstress and makes very little money from this business. Meanwhile, her husband is a motor-taxi driver and sometimes assists her brother in selling rice crops. He typically makes around $7/day in revenue. One of her children works at the garment factory and contributes her income once a month to the household. The other two children are students. Han hopes to use the loan to purchase a motorcycle and more clothes for her business. One day Chanthy hopes to own a rice crop shop.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to run a business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand and diversify her grocery business.

texts.en: Afghan Gul lives in district 1 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is educated and also very talented. She loves her husband a lot and he has a retail shop. She took her 4th cycle group loan and her husband bought retail items like packets of sweets, bars of chocolate, peaches, bags of nuts, grapefruit and extra materials to expand his business. Now his wife wants to take anther loan for her husband that he move his shop to develop close relations with other business dealers and make a good life for themselves.

loans.name: Auk

texts.en: Auk P. is 32 years old and a mother of three children, who are students. She lives with her husband in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She operates her business by selling grocery products including Chinese noodles, instant noodle soup and porridge, at the local market. She usually makes about $5/day. Her husband works at a private company as a driver and contributes his salary to help support the family. P. needs the loan to purchase some grocery items and utensils for her business.  Eventually, P. hopes to own a stand so that she no longer has to spend money renting one.  She also wishes to be able to provide an education for her children.

loans.use: To purchase some grocery products and utensils for her business.

texts.en: Loi was born in 1973 and her husband was born in 1960. They have a daughter and a son. Their daughter attends ninth grade. Their son doesn’t go to school yet. Loi sells vegetables at the local market. Her husband is a day laborer. Their income is $11 per person/month. If she gets a loan of $75, she can expand her business and save money for her daughter's school fees. They are going to repay monthly.

Anh is 47 years old. There are 7 people in her family. She sells pineapples and watermelons at the local market. Her husband farms a 4000-square-meter plot on which he grows rice and pineapples. Their income is $10 per person/month. Anh needs a loan of $75 to invest in a vegetable shop. They will repay monthly.

loans.name: Rang

texts.en: Rang is 40 years old. Her 46-year-old husband sells lottery tickets for a living. They have 2 sons, one in high school and one in secondary school. Rang  sells fruits and vegetables at the local market. Their income is $9 per person/month. Rang wants a loan of $75 so that she can increase the variety of fruits and vegetables that she offers for saL.. They will repay monthly.

loans.use: To offer a greater variety of fruits and vegetables for sale

texts.en:
Rosa has a convenience store and at night she sells hamburgers and salchipapas (dish made out of sausage and potatoes); her husband is a building custodian. With these as their main sources of income they support their two children and two grandchildren who they are responsible for. The store is located in her house, in Río Seco in Ciudad del Alto. She needs the loan to increase the inventory in the store. This is her third credit with Impro, since her good credit record allowes her to take out another loan, which will aid her in increasing the family’s income.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


Rosa tiene una tienda de abarrotes y por las noches vende Hamburguesas y salchipapas; el esposo es rentista. Estos son sus principales ingresos para la manutención de sus dos hijos y dos nietos que depende de ella. La tienda esta ubicada en su mismo domicilio, en la zona de Rió Seco de la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito requiere para incrementar mercadería en la tienda. Es el tercer crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago le habilita para sacar otro préstamo, misma que le ayudara a incrementar sus ingresos familiares.

Paulina sells candy, soda and instant noodle soups in a school (Educational unit) in Río Seco in Ciudad del Alto. With this business as her main source of income she supports her three children aged 15, 12 and 8. She lives in the same city where her business is. She will use the loan to increase the inventory in the store. This is her second credit with Impro; her good credit record has allowed her to take out another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


Paulina vende golosinas, refresco y sopa de fideo en un colegio (Unidad educativa) en la Zona de Rió Seco de la Ciudad de El Alto; esta es su principal fuente de ingresos para la manutención de sus 3 hijos de 15, 12 y 8 años de edad. Vive en la Zona de Rió Seco de la misma ciudad. El crédito lo destinara para comprar incrementar mercadería. Es el segundo crédito con Impro, el buen antecedentes crediticio le permite acceder a otro crédito.

Miriam is a single mother of three children aged 12, 10 and 7, who she supports. She works as a secretary at the Centro Comunal El Carmen, an institution that does community work in health and education. She lives in her mother’s house located in Villa Esperanza in Ciudad del Alto. She will use the loan to pay for her children’s school tuition and to buy them uniforms.

Her good credit record has allowed her to have access to another loan to see for the education of her three children.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


Miriam es madre soltera de tres hijos de 12, 10 y 7 años que dependen de ella; trabaja de secretaria en Centro Comunal El Carmen institución que trabaja con servicio social en el área de salud y educación. Vive en la casa de su madre ubicada en Zona Villa Esperanza de la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito lo destinara para pagar las pensiones de sus hijos en el colegio y la compra de uniforme escolar. El buen antecedente crediticio con Impro le permite acceder a otro crédito para cumplir con la educación de sus tres hijos.

Claudia is married and has two children aged 11 and 14. Her husband works as a security guard. Ten years ago, the need to contribute to the family’s income motivated Claudia to start selling shoes. She began helping her mother in the same business before she went independent. She enjoys sales and has since increased her client base. Thanks to her efforts she increasingly reaps more benefits from her work.

Now that the new season has begun, demand has grown for her products and she has many orders she still hasn’t filled. In order to fill them, she needs a loan of $250 which she expects to pay back in 3 to 6 months. You can contribute to the growth of this business and help this family. They sincerely appreciate your support.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


Claudia es casada y tiene dos hijos de 11 y 14 años de edad, su esposo trabaja como empleado de seguridad, y la necesidad de obtener un ingreso extra para contribuir al gasto familiar motivaron a Claudia, desde hace diez años, a iniciar con la venta de calzado, a ella le gustan las ventas y empezó ayudándole a su madre con este mismo negocio y después se independizó, ahora se ha incrementado el número de sus clientes y gracias a su esfuerzo cada vez obtiene mejores beneficios.

Ahora que ha entrado la nueva temporada, ha crecido la demanda por sus productos y tiene muchos pedidos que aun no ha surtido, para lo que requiere de un préstamo por $ 250 dólares, que espera devolver en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses, tu puedes contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio y ayudar a esta familia, ellos agradecen sinceramente tu apoyo.

Sylvia is married, and is a mother of five children. She was born in Pader, Kitgum. She left Kitgum due to political instability. When she came to Kampala, she settled at a camp for those who were internally displaced in Banda-Kireka. Life was not easy, and she had to look for means of survival. She entered the stone quarry business to earn sustenance for herself and the rest of the family. Her husband got a job with a security organization as a guard. Together, they has been able to increase their family's income.

In time she was introduced to the Life in Africa foundation. Since Sylvia knows other ladies involved in paper bead making, she found it very easy to learn how to make the beads. She is now a confident member, earning up to shsUG 150,000 per month from producing beads. She plans to build a family house at Pader where she can sleep when she visits her home district.

Sylvia's quarrying business involves paying labor for the digging of the stones, cracking them to the desired sizes, and then loading them to the customers' trucks. She used to produce two truckloads but now hopes to make three more per month with the increased capital from the loan. She will re-pay the loan in 5 months.

A. Paska is a married woman with eight children. Her children are well mannered, and she works very hard to bring them up morally, intellectually and spiritually.

She came to Kampala during the difficult times in 1997 when the Northern Uganda conflict made it unsafe for her family to stay. She took refuge in Kampala and eventually relocated to Acholi Quarter. While in Kampala, hard work is a part of her life. She started doing what she could to earn money for her family by selling sugar-canes and breaking stones. She eventually acquired her own pit and was able to earn more through dedication and hard work.

Paska's luck soon changed when she was introduced to Life in Africa. She joined and quickly started learning how to make paper beads. This brought a wonderful change in her life. She started earning more money, which was used to feed her family, pay for her school fees, and other necessities.

Paska dreams of constructing a permanent family house in the village. With peace on the horizon, people are starting to leave the camps and return home. Her family will need a house when they resettle back to Northern Uganda. For this she is requesting a loan in the amount of 150 USD. She will use the money to expand her quarry business so that she can start saving money to build her home. She will repay this loan in 6 months.

loans.name: Zarina

texts.en:
Zarina is a widow with three children. Her husband died when she had just given birth to their third child. She was left with the sole responsibility of providing for herself and her children. It was not an easy task for a woman in Uganda, but she was determined to obtain a job as a housekeeper in Kampala. It was through this job that she was introduced to Life in Africa. She has been an active member for the last six years.

Zarina was forced to leave school at a very early age due to the civil war. Her family lost everything during this conflict and she was never able to return to school. This left her with poor English skills, and she was barely able to read or write. However, she knew the values of education, and she has made it her life‘s goal to make sure that her children are all educated. This goal prompted her to look for a way to secure their future.

Zarina proved to be a smart business woman, and she saw the advantage of investing in income property. She managed to secure several loans through Life in Africa, and she built a solid housing unit in a poor section of Kampala. She has several tenants living in her property now, and she was able to pay back all her loans in a timely manner. Like any other Life in Africa member, she was among the first to take a loan of 800,000 from Kiva in May 2006. She used her loan money to plaster her house, which ensured the quality of housing for her tenants. In addition, it also insured the value and durability of her property. She has repaid her loans without ever having a single late payment. Before plastering her house, she was earning 200,000 per month and is now earning 280,000 per month.

Zarina feels that she should put a ceiling board in her four roomed house so that it may look attractive to her tenants and also may increase the house rent. Any additions to the house increase the rent, which would raise her income. To do this she is requesting a loan amount of 150 USD.

loans.use: Putting a celing board in the house

texts.en:
M. Moreen is a Muganda, who hail from Bombo, Kampala Uganda. She is married and has four children. She has two girls at their first and second years at Kampala International University, which offers developmental studies and education.

She joined Life in Africa in 2004 as an artisan. She is a designer and her living is based upon these activities.

She is extremely business oriented, but her business had not been doing so well until she joined the Life in Africa community. There have been good opportunities marketed by Life in Africa, and some have been purchased by members. She joined life in Africa in 2004, and since this time she has showed her cooperation and dedication to the community.

Moreen designs and sews lovely African clothing. She wishes to expand this business by renting land for a boutique in a strategic place at the railways of Kampala, where there are a lot of potential customers. To do this she is seeking loan of 150 USD.

K. Denis is 23 and was born in Lacekocot, a village in the Pader district. He has the responsibility in his family for paying his younger brother's school fees. Denis has managed this for several years through a small barbershop he owns, complemented by additional painting and construction work.

Denis is also an active volunteer at a charitable organization called Charity for Peace. In 2003 insecurity in Northern Uganda was intense, and many helpless children were forced to sleep on the verandas of town buildings and escape abductions from rebels in surrounding villages. Together with other Charity for Peace volunteers, Denis started finding and relocating the children to night commuter centers to keep them safe. In addition, Denis helped clean up sleeping areas and helped teach the children how to live among themselves.

For around 3 years he volunteered without earning much money until Life in Africa began offering income, generating opportunities for Charity for Peace volunteers. Denis did not stop volunteering at night, but with the Life in Africa programs he started making paper beads, peace tiles, bracelets and other crafts during the day to earn income to support himself and his family. Through Life in Africa's computer training courses, Denis is now able to operate computers. He is a hard working young man who was recently appointed to serve on Life in Africa's quality control team. This increased Denis' monthly income to nearly 240,000.

To have a job with a stable income in addition to the barbershop, Denis intends to purchase a phone set which will help him generate additional income. His sister will be in charge of the pay phone, as he will be engaged in Life in Africa activities, and she will earn part of the profit. The pay phone will be located at the Layibi railway, where his barbershop is located.

He plans to refund the loan after four months.

Michael A. is married and has two children. He had been working as a carpenter before joining Life in Africa. When he is not working at LiA, Michael works as a part-time carpenter to support his family.

Michael moved from Amuru to Gulu because of the growing conflict and dangers in Amuru. When he first moved to Gulu, he found life to be difficult, but when he began working as a carpenter again, he found the transition to be easier. He helped build the materials necessary to construct the Awere Secondary School, which offered education for displaced children. Currently, Michael leads the construction of all of Life in Africa’s buildings at the WE Gulu Center.

Currently Michael is employed with Life in Africa as the production manager. He began this job as a volunteer because he saw it was necessary to aid in the organization of the producers. His work was satisfactory, and he eventually began getting paid. He is happy with the Life in Africa program because it has greatly changed his standard of living and his family life. He can now raise over 300,000 ushs/month for his living.

Michael plans to use his loan of 150 USD to purchase a phone set. He will place the phone under the charge of his wife, and he believes that by operating the phone, he will be able to make 70,000 ushs. The money he makes from his public pay phone would be used to help pay for domestic necessities such as food and his loans.

He plans to repay the loan after a period of 3 months.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Pich T., 42 years old, has two children and lives with her husband in Preyveng, Cambodia. She and her husband make a living by running a grocery shop in the village and typically make around $4/day. Her children are students and they help her business when they are free. T. hopes the loan will assist her in increasing her business. With the loan, she will purchase various kinds of products to sell. She plans to use the remaining loan money to repair her house to protect it from leaking during rainy season.  In the future, her family hopes to own a bigger grocery store to satisfy all her clients' needs.

loans.use: To purchase some grocery products to run a business.

texts.en:
Maria and her husband Mario have been living on their land for about ten years now. They have been able to slowly build their home out of hard work, although it is still admittedly in need of much improvement. Maria has a 7 year old daughter who she works hard to feed and educate. Her husband is a field worker who is mostly employed in big farms outside of their town. Meanwhile, Maria tends to their own piece of land with the help of Mario whenever he is out of work or she really needs him. They hope to invest in fertilizer and pesticides to preserve the crops they have already planted.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of one the new Communal Banks formed in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Anzuelo Baba Communal Bank are part of an association of rice farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their organization, El Anzuelo Asociacion, works cooperatively to help their members cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. Most recently, El Anzuelo was able to start a program that improved their members access to watering services.

The members of La Asociacion El Anzuelo de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each other’s guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Baba compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Baba

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financing, they have turned to loan sharks, paying between 100% and 240% annual interest. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and earn fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is a severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.name: Soum

texts.en: Soum R. is 29 years old and is a mother of two children. She lives with her husband in Preyveng, Cambodia. She and her husband sell a variety of vegetables at the nearby market and typically make around $8/day in revenue. R. asks for $1000 loan fund to purchase more vegetables in response to a great demand of her clients.  In the future, she wants to become a wholesaler who makes more income from this kind of business.

loans.use: To buy vegetables for a business.

payments.comment: Soum Ravy has successfully repaid her loan early! Thanks to you, she was able to expand her business and improve the life of her family. Thank you for your support!

loans.name: Nhim

texts.en: Nhim C. is a mother of three children and lives with her husband in Kampung Cham, Cambodia. She and her husband run a small farm that raises domestic animals and sells them to retail outlets. They make about $5/day. Two of their children are students and another one is too young to go to school yet. C. hopes the loan will help her in growing her business. She wants to use the loan to purchase more ducks and chickens and to use remaining money to repair her house.   In the future, this couple hopes to own another piece of land to expand their animal farm and to continue supporting their children's education.

loans.use: To purchase ducks and chickens to raise and sell

loans.name: Hak

texts.en:
Hak K. S. is 56 years old and is a widow with five children. She lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since her husband passed away a few years ago, she has to work hard to feed all her children. She sells grocery products and plants rubber trees in her small plantation. She usually makes around $3/day in revenue. One of her children is a barber; two help to finance the family by driving tractors to plow soils during the cultivating season; and the rest work at a garment factory. Hak says, "I really want to grow some rubber trees in my small plantation because I think it will bring me huge amount of benefit in next seven years. I hope the loan will help me purchasing rubber trees.”
In the future, Hak would like to keep growing rubber trees in her plantation and open a big grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase some grocery products and to buy some rubber trees to grow on her plantation.

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Im S. is 38 years old, and is the mother of three children. She lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province in Cambodia. She makes her living by running a small shop, and sells cassettes, compact disks, and VCDs. Im can typically make around 5 USD/day in revenue. Her husband works as a silversmith and contributes his income to the household as well. S. hopes that with this loan, she will be able to purchase some silvers and more tools for her husband to use in his business.

In the future, S. hopes she will be able to own her own CD and VCD shop to generate additional income.

loans.use: To purchase silvers, other tools and some CDs (compact disks) for a business

payments.comment: Congratulations to Im Socheat for repaying the Kiva loan early!

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Open and stock another grocery outlet

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Start a new second-hand clothes business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To Purchase a Cow and Expand her Farming Business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more feed for his cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase 2 dairy cows and improve his Farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start a grocery shop and expand her farm

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
After the 10 year civil war in Sierra Leone, Zainab started a micro business as a hawker, selling plastic bowls and dishes.  In 2005 she joined SMT and changed her business to selling food items, such as palm oil, rice, peanuts, onions etc. in a local open market.  In 2006, Zainab decided to rent a small store for her business. 

A mother of six children, she works very hard to earn income for their school expenses and daily needs.

loans.use: Purchase diversified food stuffs (sugar, salt, rice, canned goods, etc.) to attract more customers.

loans.name: A.m.

texts.en:
A.M. started his business on a very small scale in 2003 by selling general goods from a stall in the local market.  In 2005 he joined SMT and with his first two loans was able to eventually build his own small store. Additional working capital will help him increase his inventory and improve stock rotation time.

A.M. is married with 5 children, some of who help out at the store after school.

loans.use: Purchase general merchandise stock (plastic wear, sundries, kitchen utensils, etc.)  to increase the variety of goods offered in his store, thus attracting more customers.

texts.en: Both Nhi and her husband are 31 years old. They recently left the home of their parents to strike out on their own for the first time. Nhi runs a grocery store at home. Her husband is a farmer. Their income is $6 per person/month. They hope to receive a loan of $75 to increase the inventory they offer in the grocery store. They will repay monthly.

loans.name: Maa

texts.en:
Maa's family had a small store but it got destroyed.  In early 2006, with a small amount of her own money she started a small business selling eggs, onions, and salt in the open market. Later she joined SMT and has successfully expanded her business with the on-time repaid loans she has received. This new loan will help her diversify her stock to include rice, palm oil, and peanuts.

Maa S. is 35 years old with 4 children. Her small business helps supplement the income of her husband who works as a day laborer.

loans.use: Diversify the types of products she sells in the open market.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamed M. is 26 years and had no opportunity for formal education.  During the civil war in Sierra Leone, M. was a refugee in Guinea where he learned tailoring.  When he returned from Guinea, M. settled in a village with his family and life was not easy for him.  He then came to Kabala and began to sew clothes for people using a friend’s sewing machine.

M. joined SMT and with his first loans purchased two sewing machines and rented another two.  He asked four other young men to assist him in his sewing business.  M.’s business has continued to progress and he would like to expand it.  With a new loan he plans to buy a embroidery machine and specialized thread.  M. has made himself responsible for his young sisters' and brothers’ education expenses, and his business has managed to provide continuing employment for the four other young men.

loans.use: Purchase emboidery machine and specialized thread.

loans.name: Kadi

texts.en: Kadi is 46 years old and married, although she has no children of own she is taking care of her brother's 2 children.  They are living in a rented house and her husband is unemployed.  Kadi started her business as a hawker and later established a small stall in the open market for selling mainly onions and palm oil.  When she joined SMT, she expanded her business in the same market where she was given a larger space for selling by the city council.  As her business progresses, she would like to diversity her stock for more profit. She hopes to own her own house one day.

loans.use: Diversify her inventory at her stall in the local open market.

texts.en:
Beatriz lives with her two children ages 15 and 18 in her own home in Tembladerani in the Sopocachi zone of La Paz. She is unmarried and supports her family working for the social security agency in her city. The family is living in a three-room home which is not yet completed as the brick walls still need to be plastered. This loan will pay to plaster, paint and trim in the home's interior. This is the first loan Mrs. O. has requested from IMPRO. Our credit check shows she will be able to repay the loan.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Beatriz vive con sus dos hijos de 15 y 18 años en su vivienda de la zona de Tembladerani, zona sopocachi de la ciudad de La Paz, no tiene esposo, por lo que la señora mantiene a la familia trabajando en la institución de seguro social de esta ciudad. La casa de la señora Beatriz cuenta con tres habitaciones que las están habitando pero que aun no están concluidas en su construcción, pues están en obra gruesa (muros de ladrillo y cemento sin revoque). El destino del crédito es para el acabado en obra fina de tres habitaciones; revoque, carpintería y pintura interior. Es la primera ocasión que la señora O. solicita un préstamo en nuestra institución y el análisis crediticio muestran que podrá cubrir sus obligaciones producto del crédito.

Thuong is 47 years old. Her husband died a long time ago. She supports 3 sons whose ages are 15, 13, and 6. The eldest stopped going to school to earn money.  The other 2 sons attend primary school. Thuong runs a small grocery store from her home. Their income is $7 per person/month. Thuong hopes to receive a loan of $75 to invest in her grocery store. She will repay monthly.

Martha lives in her own home on Ricardo Bustamante Street in the Villa Nuevo Potosi neighborhood. She is 45 years old. Her husband has health problems and lives in Santa Cruz so Martha cares for their children in La Paz. She has been selling fruit for ten years. This loan is to increase her working capital. At this time she sells the fruit wholesale as it arrives from El Alto and sells the remainder at her stand on Buenos Aires Avenue in La Paz. Her previous history with IMPRO gives her favored status so she can receive this loan.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer

Martha vive en casa propia en la calle Ricardo Bustamante de la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí; tiene 45 años de edad, el esposo tiene problemas de salud por lo cual el vive en Santa Cruz, ella se hace cargo de sus hijos en la ciudad de la Paz, se dedica a la venta de fruta desde hace mas de 10 años con lo cual mantiene a su familia. El crédito que solicita es para aumentar su capital ya que ahora vende al por mayor cuando llega la fruta en la Ciudad de El Alto y lo que sobra vende en su puesto ubicado en la Av. Buenos Aires de la ciudad de La Paz. Su antecedente histórico con Impro, la califica como cliente preferencial y puede acceder un nuevo crédito.

payments.comment: Early pay off. client is applying for a new loan.

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 24 years old. He would like to enhance his living standard and increase his income. He has a small shop in Kirkuk to repair and maintain washing machines. His poor family didn't send him to school. When he was 7 years old, he worked with his father to help him in the shop. He applied to get $1200 from Al-Aman to develop his small shop and buy new equipment.

His wife is expecting their first child. As he said,"I want to see my children in school."

Note: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, etc.).

loans.use: To develop his shop and buy new equipment

texts.en:
Isabel sells music CD's and videos. She buys them wholesale for retail sale. She lives in the Villa Mayor neighborhood in La Paz and sells in fairs like the July 16th fair in El Alto. Her track record with our institution qualifies her as a class 2 borrower, which is to say she has a record of regular repayment. This loan will pay for merchadise. Her experience recommends her for this loan and she will have income to repay it.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer

Isabel es comerciante y se dedica a la venta de Videos y Cds musicales , compra por mayor para venderlo al detalle. Vive en la zona de villa victoria de la Ciudad de La Paz, y su puesto esta ubicado en las ferias como la 16 de julio de la Ciudad de El Alto. Su historial en nuestra institución la califica como cliente 2, es decir con cumplimiento regular en el pago de su obligación. El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra mercaderia (Cds, Vds. Musicales y videos) Su trabajo le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio. El cual le da ingresos para cubrir el préstamo.

This entrepreneur is 29 years old and married with two children. One of them is in school. He has an electric materials shop in the Kirkuk market.

This is his first loan. He wants to get $1000 to buy electric materials from another city and bring them to Kirkuk. He is looking to develop his shop and bring more goods.
